{{Year nav topic5|1605|music}}
The year '''1605 in [[music]]''' involved some significant events.
==Events== *''none listed''
==Publications== *[[William Byrd]] – ''Gradualia'', book one *[[Claudio Monteverdi]] – {{Lang-it|Il quinto libro de madrigali a cinque voci di Claudio Monteverdi Maestro della Musica del Serenissimo Sig.r Duca di Mantoa, col basso continuo per il Clavicembano, Chittarone, od altro simile istromento; fatto particolarmente per li sei ultimi, per li altri a beneplacito}} (fifth book of [[Madrigal (music)|madrigals]] ''a''5), published in [[Venice]] *[[Michael Praetorius]] – ''Musae Sionae'', Part 1 *[[Tomás Luis de Victoria]] – ''[[Officium Defunctorum (Victoria)|Officium Defunctorum]], sex vocibus, in obitu et obsequiis sacrae imperatricis''
==Classical music==
==Opera== *''none listed''
==Births== *March – [[Antonio Bertali]], Italian composer (died 1669) *April – [[Giacomo Carissimi]], composer (died 1674) *[[April 19]] – [[Orazio Benevoli]], composer (died 1672) *[[July 9]] – [[Simon Dach]], hymn-writer (died 1659) *[[September 17]] – [[Francesco Sacrati]], early opera composer (died 1650) *''date unknown'' – [[Constantia Zierenberg]], singer and musician (died 1653) *''probable'' **[[Johann Vierdanck]], violinist, cornettist, and composer (died 1646) **[[Julius Johann Weiland]], composer (died 1663)
==Deaths== *[[February 19]] – [[Orazio Vecchi]], Italian composer (born 1550) *[[September 24]] – [[Manuel Mendes]], composer and music teacher (born c. 1547) *''date unknown'' – [[Pedro Bermúdez]], composer and chapel-master (born 1558)
{{DEFAULTSORT:1605 In Music}} [[Category:1605|Music]] [[Category:17th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

[[Image:Brasão Castelo Rodrigo.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The shield of the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[town]] of [[Castello Rodrigo]], inverted for the town's treachery in the [[1383–1385 Crisis]]]]
An '''abatement''' (or '''rebatement''') is a modification of a [[coat of arms]], representing a less-than honorable [[augmentation of arms|augmentation]],<ref>{{Cite book | last1=Boutell | first1=Charles | last2=Fox-Davies | first2=Arthur Charles | lastauthoramp=yes | title=The handbook to English heraldry | publisher=Reeves & Turner | place= | volume= | edition= | year=1914 | quote=Abatement is a term which was unknown until it made its appearance in certain heraldic writings of the sixteenth century, when it was used to denote such marks or devices as, by the writers in question, were held to be the reverse of honourable Augmentation—Augmentations of dishonour indeed, and tokens of degradation. | page=207 | url=https://books.google.com/books?pg=PA207&dq=abatement+heraldry&id=_xdMAAAAMAAJ#v=onepage&q=abatement%20heraldry&f=false }}</ref><ref>{{ Citation | last1=Boutell | first1=Charles | lastauthoramp=yes | title=Heraldry, historical and popular, With 975 Illustrations | publisher=Richard Bentley | place= | volume= | edition=3rd | year=1864 | quote=Abatement: - any sign of degradation | page=77 | url=https://books.google.com/books?pg=PR3&dq=abatement+heraldry&id=w6RAAAAAcAAJ#v=onepage&q=abatement&f=false }}</ref> imposed by an heraldic authority (such as the [[Court of Chivalry]] in England) or by royal decree for misconduct. The practice of inverting the entire [[escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]] of an [[armiger]] found guilty of high [[treason]] has been attested since the [[Middle Ages]] and is generally accepted as reliable, and medieval heraldic sources cite at least one instance of removing an honourable charge from a coat of arms by royal decree as an abatement of honour. Other abatements of honour implied by the addition of dishonourable [[Stain (heraldry)|stains]] and [[Charge (heraldry)|charges]], appearing in late 16th-century texts, have never been reliably attested in actual practice. Additionally, as many heraldic writers note, the use of arms is not compulsory, so armigers are more likely to relinquish a dishonored coat of arms than to advertise their dishonor.
==Inverted arms== The earliest mention in heraldic writing of a dishonorable display of arms (and, according to Fox-Davies, the only one reliably attested in actual use; see historical examples below)<ref name=Fox-Davies /> was inverting the entire shield, first documented by [[Johannes de Bado Aureo]] in his heraldic treatise ''Tractatus de armis'' (c. 1394).<ref name=laurel>{{Cite web |url=http://heraldry.sca.org/laurel/abate.html |last=Levin |first=Craig |title=Abatements and Augmentations of Honor |year=2004 |accessdate=2012-08-11}}</ref> Contemporary accounts of executions for treason describe the traitor being marched to his execution in a paper tabard displaying his inverted arms,<ref name=Fox-Davies /> and other accounts tell of displaying the inverted arms of prisoners, released on parole, who refuse to pay their ransom.<ref name=laurel />
==Theoretical abatements== Eight other abatements were introduced in the late 16th century, each prescribing a specific charge in a specific [[Stain (heraldry)|stain]] for a specific offense; though the charges themselves were uncommon but no less honourable than any other charge (if colored in any standard tincture or fur), it was only when displayed in the prescribed position and stain that these charges were supposed to be considered dishonourable.
Leigh (1562) enumerated the nine abatements thus:<ref name=Oxford />
#Point dexter parted [[tenné]], for false claims of valor #Point champaine tenné, for killing a prisoner who has demanded quarter #Plain point [[sanguine (heraldry)|sanguine]], for one who lies to his sovereign #Point in point sanguine, for cowardice #Gusset sanguine borne to dexter, for adultery, or to sinister for a drunkard #Gore sinister tenné, for cowardice in the face of the enemy #Delf tenné, for revoking a challenge #Inescutcheon reversed sanguine, for any man who "discourteously entreateth eyther maid or widow against her will, or flieth from his Soveraignes banner"<ref>Leigh, G. ''The Accedence of Armory,'' 1st ed. (London:1562). Quoted in Woodcock (1988), p.68.</ref> #The entire escutcheon inverted, for treason
Scottish herald [[Thomas Innes of Learney]] mentioned abatements in marital situations: "The law of arms provides for abating the arms of an adulterer by two gussets sanguine, and where the bearing of arms is necessary this, and one gusset (they will be close-gussets) for non-adulterous divorcees, are, at least in Patents, applied in the case of divorcees."<ref name=IH>{{Cite web |url=http://www.internationalheraldry.com/ |title=Abatements |publisher=InternationalHeraldry.com |accessdate=2012-08-12}}</ref>
Several notable modern heraldists have asserted that the execution of this system of abatements has never been attested in fact, and that the whole system was in all likelihood a theoretical exercise created by heralds for the purpose of discouraging armigers from committing dishonourable acts.<ref name=Fox-Davies>{{Cite book |last=Fox-Davies |first=Arthur Charles |authorlink=Arthur Charles Fox-Davies |year=1909 |title=A Complete Guide to Heraldry |location=London |publisher=T.C. & E.C. Jack |pages=72–3}}</ref><ref name=Oxford>{{Cite book |last1=Woodcock |first1=Thomas |authorlink1=Thomas Woodcock (officer of arms) |last2=Robinson |first2=John Martin |authorlink2=John Martin Robinson |year=1988 |title=The Oxford Guide to Heraldry |location=Oxford, England |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=0192116584 |page=68}}</ref>
==Breaking or erasing charges== [[File:Lion Coward.svg|thumb|right|150px|A lion ''couard'' is said to denote dishonor or cowardice.]] As another form of abatement, some coats of arms were reportedly modified through breaking or cutting, reversing, or altogether erasing some existing charges, at least as they occur in patents, though the armiger's actual display of these defaced arms has not been documented and is unlikely.
In [[French heraldry]] the term ''diffamé'' is used to denote a lion or other animal whose tail is cut off, or may refer more broadly to arms which have been altered to signify loss of honor. A lion with its tail between its hind legs is termed "couard" (coward), and has also been cited as a mark of infamy.<ref name=IH />
Though lions are traditionally depicted with male genitals, a recent trend toward omitting the genitals has been controversial, prodding claims that emasculated lions have also been an historical form of abatement. Commenting on the newly castrated lion in the arms of the [[Nordic Battle Group]] in 2007, Vladimir Sagerlund, heraldic artist at the [[Swedish National Archives]] since 1994, was critical of the politically motivated decision, stating, "once upon a time coats of arms containing lions without genitalia were given to those who betrayed the Crown."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.se/9398.html |title=Army castrates heraldic lion |last=O'Mahony |first=Paul |work=The Local: Sweden's News in English |publisher=The Local Europe AB (Stockholm) |date=2007-12-13 |accessdate=2009-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gp.se/gp/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=119&a=388755 |title=Kvinnor fick lejonet stympat |last=Ullgren |first=Sven |work=Göteborgs Posten |publisher=Göteborgs-Posten (Gothenburg, Sweden) |language=Swedish |date=2007-12-12 |accessdate=2009-03-30 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071217161423/http://www.gp.se/gp/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=119&a=388755 |archivedate = December 17, 2007}}</ref> ''The Times'' in London, however, noted a growing recent trend toward heraldic "castration", pointing to the lions passant on the royal [[coat of arms of England]], as well as the lions rampant on [[Coat of arms of Norway|those of Norway]], [[Coat of arms of Finland|Finland]], [[Coat of arms of Belgium|Belgium]], [[Coat of arms of Luxembourg|Luxembourg]] and [[Coat of arms of Scotland|Scotland]], all of which have recently been depicted without genitals; in conclusion, ''The Times'' wrote, "some crests are ambiguous, but the message remains clear: the lions are supposed to display courage and nothing else."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article3054270.ece |title=Military lion shorn of his equipment after women troops protest |last=Boyes |first=Roger |work=Times Online |publisher=Times Newspapers Ltd. (London) |date=2007-12-15 |accessdate=2009-03-30}}</ref> While such arms are clearly not intended as an abatement in modern times, no known examples of castrated lions have been found in medieval heraldry.
==Reported historical examples== A few examples of historical abatements of arms have been recorded, though none of these reflect the addition of stained ordinaries as detailed above. Rather, these include broken chevrons, disarmed lions, and reversed or erased charges.
One of these rare historical examples was [[Amery of Pavy]], who was appointed governor of [[Calais]] by King [[Edward III of England]] in 1347, and whose arms were abated by royal decree in 1349 after the failed French [[Siege of Calais (1348)|siege of Calais]] on the last day of December 1348, which resulted from Sir Amery's attempt to sell Calais to [[Geoffroi de Charny|Sir Geffrey Charney]], the French governor of nearby [[Saint-Omer]], for 20,000 [[Crown (English coin)|crowns]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Bicknell |first=W. I. |year=1846 |title=Payne's Illustrated London |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zBAHAAAAQAAJ |location=London |publisher=Brain and Payne |pages=146–7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Froissart |first=John |year=1844 |title=The Chronicles of England, France and Spain |url=https://archive.org/stream/chroniclesofengl01froi1#page/n11/mode/2up |location=London |publisher=William Smith |pages=192–5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Gifford |first=John |year=1792 |title=The History of France: From the Earliest Times to the Present Important Era |volume=Volume II |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4vg_AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA53#v=onepage&q&f=false |location=London |publisher=C. Lowndes and W. Locke |page=53}}</ref> As stated by Sir George Mackenzie: "And [[Edward III of England|Edward the Third of England]] ordained two of six [[star (heraldry)|stars]] which a gentleman had in his arms to be effaced, because he had sold a seaport of which he was made governor."<ref name=IH /><ref name=Parker>{{Cite web |url=http://karlwilcox.com/parker/?page_id=203 |last=Parker |first=James |title=Abatements |work=Parker's Heraldry |publisher=Karl B. Wilcox |accessdate=2012-08-12}}</ref> [[Pursuivant|Pursuivant of arms]] [[John Guillim]], writing circa 1610, gave the story in considerable detail, adding that Sir Amery's arms were also inverted for his treachery. Guillim further explained that this humiliation is not inherited by the traitor's heirs, up to and including [[capital crime]]s, except in cases of [[high treason]].<ref name=Guillim>{{cite book |last=Guillim |first=John |date=1611 |title=A Display of Heraldrie |chapter=Section I Chapter VIII |url=http://www.btinternet.com/~paul.j.grant/guillim/s1/gu_s1c8.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015165207/http://www.btinternet.com/~paul.j.grant/guillim/s1/gu_s1c8.htm |archivedate=2008-10-15 |location=London |publisher=Printed by William Hall for Raphe Mab}}</ref>
An example of a lion ''diffamée'' is that of [[John I, Count of Hainaut|Jean d'Avesnes]] who insulted his mother, [[Margaret II, Countess of Flanders]], in the presence of [[Louis IX of France|King Louis IX]]. He is supposed to have seen the lion in his arms ''diffamée'' (i.e. the tail removed) and ''morné'' (i.e. the teeth and claws removed).<ref name=IH />
==See also== *[[Augmentation of honour]] *[[Bend sinister (heraldry)]] *[[Stain (heraldry)]]

[[Category:Heraldry]]

{{About|the series of events organised by the multinational alcoholic beverages company Diageo|the Roman Catholic saint whose feast day is unrelated|Saint Arthur|more details on Arthur Guinness, the founder of Guinness brewing|Arthur Guinness}} {{Use Irish English|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Arthur's Day | image = Guinness 250 Anniversary 1759-2009.jpg | caption = To Arthur! | location = [[Dublin]], Ireland
[[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia
[[Lagos]], Nigeria
New York, United States
[[Yaoundé]], Cameroon | years_active = 5 | dates = 24 September 2009
23 September 2010
22 September 2011
27 September 2012
26 September 2013 | genre = | website = http://www.guinness.com/en-ie/arthursday/ }} '''Arthur's Day''' was an annual series of music events worldwide, originally organised by [[Diageo]] in 2009 to promote the 250th anniversary of its [[Guinness]] brewing company. The 2009 events took place, internationally, in the cities of [[Dublin]], [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Lagos]], New York and [[Yaoundé]] on 23 September 2009. The event was broadcast internationally on [[Sky Digital (UK & Ireland)|Sky TV]], [[ITV2]] and [[DirecTV]].{{cite web|author=Mark Coughlan|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS186320+08-Sep-2009+PRN20090908|title=GUINNESS Announces Further Details for Arthur's Day Global Celebrations|date=8 September 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|agency=Reuters }} €6 million was pledged to the Arthur Guinness Fund at the time. The so-called celebration was endorsed by several high-profile names, such as rock star-turned political activist [[Bob Geldof]], director and screenwriter [[Guy Ritchie]], footballer and Guinness football ambassador for Africa [[Michael Essien]] and British celebrities such as [[Peter Crouch]] and [[Sophie Dahl]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.com/article.cfm?id=38200 |title=Celebrated by celebrities—People around the world are raising their glasses to wish Guinness a happy 250th birthday on Arthur's Day |date=18 August 2009 |accessdate=18 September 2009 |work=[[The Sun (Malaysia)|The Sun]] (Malaysia) }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Notable high-profile names who later spoke out against Arthur's day include: director [[Lenny Abrahamson]], singer-songwriter [[Christy Moore]], and musician [[Mike Scott (musician)|Mike Scott]] of [[The Waterboys]]. The event was also dubbed "Diageo Day" by [[The Huffington Post]] to promote a boycott of the event.{{cite web|author=Rory Fitzgerald|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rory-fitzgerald/boycott-guinness-on-arthu_b_1916921.html|title=Boycott Guinness on Arthur's Day – or Should That Be "Diageo Day"?|date=26 September 2012|accessdate=21 September 2013|work=The Huffington Post}} The Royal College of Physicians Ireland highlighted a 30% increase in ambulance call-outs on each successive Arthur's Day and a doubling in alcohol-related liver disease over the previous decade, associated with drink promotion and the relative cheapness of alcohol.{{cite web|author=Lyndsey Telford|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/doctors-slam-arthurs-day-as-drinkrelated-deaths-rise-29598566.html|title=Doctors slam 'Arthur's Day' as drink-related deaths rise|date=23 September 2013|work=The Irish Independent}} Guinness drinkers were asked by the brewing company to raise a glass to the memory of [[Arthur Guinness]] at 17:59 (5:59 pm), a reference to 1759, the year the Guinness Brewery was established.{{cite web|author=Roddy L'Estrange|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2009/0812/1224252419950.html|title=Beaumont pint would make Arthur turn in his grave|date=12 August 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|work=The Irish Times |quote=There were ads on, one of which he'd seen before. It was for "Arthur's Day" to mark the 250th anniversary of the signing of the 9,000-year lease at the St James' Gate Brewery by Arthur Guinness. The day picked out by the Guinness marketing people was Thursday 24 September when, at precisely 17:59, the intention was for Guinness drinkers everywhere to raise a glass of the black stuff and toast the memory of the great man.}}{{cite web|url=http://www.herald.ie/opinion/growing-up-in-the-shadow-of-arthur-g-1892970.html|title=Growing up in the shadow of Arthur G|date=22 September 2009|accessdate=22 September 2009|work=[[Evening Herald]]}} An 82c stamp of an Arthur Guinness portrait was also released by [[An Post]] to commemorate the anniversary.{{cite web|author=Mark Coughlan|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0828/1224253402209.html|title=Stamp of approval for Arthur Guinness|date=28 August 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|work=The Irish Times |quote=The 82c stamp, featuring an 18th-century portrait of Arthur Guinness by an unknown artist, covers airmail letter postage to any part of the world. [...] "It's a fitting tribute from An Post to dedicate a stamp to mark our 250th anniversary."}} The last Arthur's Day was held in 2013. Guinness cancelling the event in 2014. A new music programme to help emerging artists in Ireland called ''Guinness Amplify'' was launched to replace the event{{cite web|url= http://www.rte.ie/news/2014/0702/628069-guinness/|title= Guinness cancels Arthur's Day after five years|date=3 July 2014|work=RTÉ News|accessdate=29 January 2015}}{{cite web|url= http://www.dailyedge.ie/arthurs-day-axed-guinness-amplify-1550182-Jul2014/|title= Arthur’s Day axed: Guinness confirms celebration will not be returning|date=3 July 2014|work=Daily Edge|accessdate=29 January 2015}} ==Marketing== The event was criticised as a marketing ploy to increase sales of Guinness with Arthur's day, without understanding or appreciation for the sense of nostalgia and meaning behind the "Black Stuff" that the event promoted according to Diageo. Diageo also claimed that Arthur's Day was held on a Thursday, rather than an accurate yearly basis on the original date. Thursday was chosen according to Diageo as Thursdays were the traditional "student night" in Dublin and many towns in Ireland.{{cite web|author=Michael Clifford|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0828/1224253402209.html|title=We're buying into cheap marketing ploys|date=24 September 2011|accessdate=24 September 2011|work=The Irish Times |quote=In reality, it is a cynical marketing ploy by the international drinks firm, Diageo, which owns Guinness. [...] "In reality, it is a cynical marketing ploy by the international drinks firm, Diageo, which owns Guinness."}} ''[[The Irish Times]]'' has described Arthur's Day as "a masterclass in how to fabricate a national holiday" with its "''[[à la carte]]'' attitude to traditional holidays" – noting its countdown to one minute before six (recalling New Year's Eve), "the faux-patriotism that comes with a celebration of a "national" drink" and the "[[hagiography|hagiographic]] treatment" of Arthur Guinness as some kind of [[saint]]. The paper warned, "If St Patrick's Day, Christmas, and Hallowe'en are festivals that offer an excuse for a drink, Diageo has flipped the concept on its head and made the drink an excuse for a festival".{{cite news|first=Dan|last=Griffin|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/0927/breaking50.html|title=Arthur's Day: fabrication and libation|newspaper=The Irish Times|publisher=Irish Times Trust|date=27 September 2012|accessdate=27 September 2012}} ==By year== ===2009=== ;Dublin The Dublin shows occurred in four major venues ([[The Academy (music venue)|The Academy]], Tripod, [[Vicar Street]] and [[Whelan's (music venue)|Whelan's]]), 28 [[public house]]s and a specially established venue called Hop Store 13 at [[St. James's Gate Brewery]]. The events saw several high-profile acts performing in smaller locations than usual, with the likes of Tom Jones playing in a small Dublin pub. Admission prices referenced the well-known Guinness numbers, €9.99 and €17.59.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/theticket/2009/0717/1224250811255.html|title=Catch Tom Jones in your local|date=17 July 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|work=The Irish Times |quote=Gigs will be split between four main venues in Dublin (The Academy, Vicar Street, Tripod and Whelan's) as well as 28 other pubs... St James's Gate. Tickets are on sale from Ticketmaster from next Tuesday, and are €9.99 and €17.59.}} The line-ups were confirmed on 24 July 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/theticket/2009/0724/1224251197793.html|title=Arthur's Day line-ups|date=24 July 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|work=The Irish Times }} The events at Hop Store 13 would be hosted by [[Cat Deeley]] and [[Ronan Keating]], whilst [[Colin Murray]], [[Michelle Doherty]] and [[Michelle de Swarte]] would present from the other four major venues in the city. {| class="wikitable" | The Academy || Tripod || Vicar Street || Whelan's |- valign="top" | * [[Richard Hawley]] * [[The Kooks]] * [[Imelda May]] * [[Paolo Nutini]] * [[Fionn Regan]] {{ns|9}} || * [[Calvin Harris]] * [[Jamie Cullum]] * [[Mongrel (band)|Mongrel]] * [[Republic of Loose]] * [[Roots Manuva]] * [[Soul II Soul]] {{ns|11}} || * [[Black Swan Effect]] * [[The Blizzards]] * [[The Magic Numbers]] * [[Ok Go]] * [[Razorlight]] * [[Reverend and The Makers]]{{ns}} * [[Sugababes]] || * [[The Enemy (UK band)|The Enemy]] * [[David Gray (musician)|David Gray]] * [[Lisa Hannigan]] * [[The Hot Rats]] * [[Noah and the Whale]] * [[The Undertones]] * [[The Wombats]] |} The Dublin events was headlined by [[Estelle (musician)|Estelle]], [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]], [[Kasabian]] and [[Sugababes]]. [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]] was one of the acts to play Hop Store 13 before being taken to a secret location elsewhere in the city to perform again.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/weekend/2009/0829/1224253451948.html|title=It's not unusual to be loved by all|date=29 August 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|work=The Irish Times |quote=Jones will be arriving in Dublin on 24 September (aka Arthur's Day) for two special shows in celebration of the 250th anniversary of Guinness. While he and other acts performed at Hop Store 13 during the day and evening, he also, at an unspecified time, was whisked off to a city-centre pub for a 30-minute, sweaty, in-your-face, eyeball-to-eyeball gig. So – a Tom Jones gig. In a Dublin pub. Belting out the likes of Delilah, Thunderball, What's New Pussycat? and It's Not Unusual. We can already envisage the roof of that particular Dublin pub being blown off by sheer force of personality and audience reaction.}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/arts/2009/0814/arthursday.html|title=Tom Jones to play Guinness brewery|date=14 August 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}} Other acts include [[The Blizzards]], The Chakras, [[The Chapters]], [[Concerto For Constantine]], [[The Coronas]], [[Jamie Cullum]], [[Dirty Epics]], [[The Enemy (UK band)|The Enemy]], [[Mick Flannery]], [[General Fiasco]], [[David Gray (musician)|David Gray]], [[Calvin Harris]], [[Richard Hawley]], [[The High Kings]], [[Hoarsebox]], [[David Holmes (musician)|David Holmes]], [[The Infomatics]], [[Jerry Fish & The Mudbug Club]], [[David Kitt]], [[The Kooks]], [[The Magic Numbers]], [[Roots Manuva]], [[Imelda May]], [[Fiona Melady]], [[Mystery Jets]], [[Noah and the Whale]], [[Noise Control]], [[Paolo Nutini]], [[OK Go]], [[Oppenheimer (band)|Oppenheimer]], [[Razorlight]], [[Fionn Regan]], [[Republic of Loose]], [[Reverend and The Makers]], [[Sharon Shannon]], [[Soul II Soul]], [[The Undertones]], [[White Belt Yellow Tag]] and [[The Wombats]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hotpress.com/archive/5805670.html|title=More additions to Arthur's Day bill|date=8 September 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|work=[[Hot Press]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hotpress.com/archive/5689862.html|title=Guinness announce Arthur's Day line-up|date=15 July 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|work=[[Hot Press]]}}{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.ie/music/music-news-article.asp?NewsID=28836 |title=Guinness Announce Arthurs Day Line Up, Entertainment.ie Chat to Noah and The Whale |date=16 July 2009 |accessdate=12 September 2009 |publisher=[[entertainment.ie]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615014949/http://entertainment.ie/music/music-news-article.asp?NewsID=28836 |archivedate=15 June 2011 |df= }} ;Belfast Celebrations were led in [[Belfast]] by Paul and Michael at [[Cutter's]], [[The Botanic Inn]] and The House. ;Kuala Lumpur [[The Black Eyed Peas]] headlined the Arthur's Day events in [[Sunway Lagoon]] in [[Kuala Lumpur]]. The Malaysian government had initially forbidden Muslims to attend as it contradicts [[sharia]] law due to the organiser promoting alcohol, a beverage which Muslims are not allowed to drink. Non-Muslims in Malaysia were allowed to attend if they wish.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/theticket/2009/0904/1224253804084.html|title=Guinness's sharia hitch|date=4 September 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|work=The Irish Times |quote=The Malaysian leg of the Arthur's Day celebration hit a snag earlier this week, when it was revealed that the government banned Muslims from attending.}}{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/muslims-banned-from-guinness-gig-1872224.html|title=Muslims banned from Guinness gig|date=28 August 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|work=[[Irish Independent]]}} Contrary to previous regulations, anyone above the age of 18 years can now participate. ;Galway In 2010, an outdoor Arthur's Day gig took place at Folan Quay, Galway Harbour. Acts that performed on the day included Imelda May, Newton Faulkner, Empire Saints, Sharon Shannon, The Magic Numbers, David Gray.{{cite web|url=http://www.guinness.com/en-ie/arthursday/listing.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110923163318/http://www.guinness.com/en-ie/arthursday/listing.html |archivedate=23 September 2011 |df=dmy }} ;Lagos [[Sean Paul]] headlined the Arthur's Day events in [[Lagos]].{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/theticket/2009/0911/1224254253841.html|title=Acts for Guinness birthday bash|date=11 September 2009|accessdate=12 September 2009|work=The Irish Times |quote=Ronan Keating and Cat Deeley hosted the main event in Dublin, at the invite- only Hopstore 13 venue at St. James's Gate. The four studio venues (Whelan's, Tripod, the Academy and Vicar St) hosted by the BBC's Colin Murray, Phantom FM's Michelle Doherty and TV presenter Michelle de Swarte. At the same time, Sean Paul played in Lagos, Nigeria, and Black Eyed Peas headlined a show in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.}} ===2010=== On 3 June 2010, Arthur's Day 2010 was confirmed and the following acts were announced: [[Snow Patrol]], [[Paolo Nutini]], [[José González (singer)|José González]], [[Royseven]], [[The View (band)|The View]], We Have Band, [https://web.archive.org/web/20100527035724/http://www.milkthegroup.com/ MILK], [[Broken Records (band)|Broken Records]], [[Mick Flannery]], The Rags, [[John Spillane]], [[Jay Sean]], [[The Hoosiers]], [[Slow Club]], [[The Maccabees (band)|The Maccabees]], [[The Magic Numbers]], [[Sharon Shannon]], [[The High Kings]], [[The Chapters]], [[The Dirty 9s]], [[Heathers (band)|Heathers]] and [[Dirty Epics]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hotpress.com/Snow%20Patrol/news/Guinness-Arthurs-Day-2010-LineUp-Confirmed/6538047.html|title=Guinness Arthur's Day 2010 Line-Up Confirmed|date=3 June 2010|accessdate=3 June 2010|work=[[Hot Press]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100604235703/http://www.hotpress.com/Snow%20Patrol/news/Guinness-Arthurs-Day-2010-LineUp-Confirmed/6538047.html| archivedate= 4 June 2010 | deadurl= no}} Applications from musical acts were requested.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotpress.com/Guinness%20Our%20Thursdays/news/Race-to-play-Arthurs-Day-hots-up/6654136.html|title=Race to play Arthur's Day hots up|date=28 June 2010|accessdate=28 June 2010|work=[[Hot Press]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100701235355/http://www.hotpress.com/Guinness%20Our%20Thursdays/news/Race-to-play-Arthurs-Day-hots-up/6654136.html| archivedate= 1 July 2010 | deadurl= no}} For 2010, events occurred in [[Cork (city)|Cork]], Dublin and [[Galway]] on 23 September. On 28 July it was confirmed via The Victims Official website that [[Brandon Flowers]] would also be playing in support of his solo album, ''[[Flamingo]]''. {| class="wikitable" | [[St. James's Gate]] || [[Vicar Street]] || [[Olympia Theatre, Dublin|Olympia Theatre]] || [[The Academy (music venue)|The Academy]] || [[The Village (music venue)|The Village]] |-valign="top" | * [[Snow Patrol]] * [[Westlife]] * [[Manic Street Preachers]] * [[Biffy Clyro]] * Maud in Cahoots || * [[The Courteeners]] * [[The Script]] * [[The Maccabees (band)|The Maccabees]] * [[The Hoosiers]] * [[Eliza Doolittle (singer)|Eliza Doolittle]] || * [[Cathy Davey]] * [[Carbon/Silicon]] * [[The Carpenters]] * [[Dave Peyton]] || * [[Brandon Flowers]] * [[Plan B (British musician)|Plan B]] * [[Tim Robbins]] & The Rogues Gallery Band * [[José González (singer)|José González]] * [[Slow Club]] || * [[Kelis]] * [[Tinie Tempah]] * [[Ty (rapper)|Ty]] * [[Example (rapper)|Example]] * We Have Band |} * The Savoy – Cork: [[Paolo Nutini]], [[Sharon Corr]], [[The View (band)|The View]], [[Fortune (band)|Fortune]], O Emperor, Reko. * Folan Quay – Galway: [[David Gray (musician)|David Gray]], [[Imelda May]], [[Newton Faulkner]], [[The Magic Numbers]], [[Sharon Shannon]], Empire Saints. ;Kuala Lumpur The Guinness Arthur's Day 2010 was held on 24 September 2010 (GMT/UTC +8) at Surf Beach @ [[Sunway Lagoon]] and featured performances by [[Flo Rida]], [[Sean Kingston]], [[Colby O'Donis]], [[Mizz Nina]], [[Pop Shuvit]], [[Thaitanium]], Melissa Indot and DJ Fuzz. ;Indonesia Arthur's Day in Indonesia was celebrated for the first time on 4 December 2010 at the Oval Plaza Epicentrum Walk, Jakarta. [[Lifehouse (band)|Lifehouse]], the American alternative rock band which came to prominence in 2001 with their hit single 'Hanging by a moment', performed in front of more than 4,000 fans. They were supported on the day by [[Rivermaya]], a popular band from the Philippines and two hit Indonesian bands; [[Superman Is Dead]] and [[Pure Saturday]]. Winners of the Guinness Bold Chemistry took center stage along with these international talents. The huge music concert was also host to other remarkable elements such as a Guinness timeline, photo booths and Guinness Ice Bar. A revolutionary facet of the event called the [[Wooz.in]] was introduced to fans which allowed them to tag themselves at the event on Foursquare and upload photos to Facebook or Twitter via an RFID bracelet. Fans joined together at this monumentous occasion to celebrate this remarkable day and raise a toast to Arthur. ===2011=== {{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/galaxy-of-stars-ready-to-shine-as-capital-celebrates-arthurs-day-2884127.html|title=Galaxy of stars ready to shine as capital celebrates Arthur's Day|date= 21 September 2011|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=22 September 2011}} {| class="wikitable" | [[St. James's Gate]] || [[Olympia Theatre, Dublin|Olympia Theatre]] || [[Vicar Street]] || [[The Academy (music venue)|The Academy]] || [[Ulster Hall]] || Big Top, Limerick || The Savoy, Cork |-valign="top" | * [[Stereophonics]] * [[Paolo Nutini]] * [[Yasmin (musician)|Yasmin]] * [[The Saturdays]] || * [[Scissor Sisters]] * [[Aloe Blacc]] * [[Ed Sheeran]] * [[Wolf Gang (band)|Wolf Gang]] * [[Florrie]] || * [[The Charlatans (UK band)|The Charlatans]] * [[Bell X1]] * [[Labrinth]] * [[James Walsh (musician)|James Walsh]] * Sunday Girl * [[Maverick Sabre]] || * [[Paloma Faith]] * [[Big Talk]] * Bitches With Wolves * [[Joshua Radin]] * [[Miles Kane]] * [[Ryan Sheridan (musician)|Ryan Sheridan]] || * [[The Enemy (UK band)|The Enemy]] * [[Horslips]] * [[Kelis]] * [[Ash (band)|Ash]] * [[DJ Fresh]] * Cashier No.9 || * [[Calvin Harris]] * [[The Feeling]] * [[Fight Like Apes]] * [[Sharon Shannon]] * [[Jamie Woon]] * [[Royseven]] || * [[Seasick Steve]] * [[The Divine Comedy (band)|Neil Hannon]] * [[Wretch 32]] * [[Niall Breslin|Bressie]] * [[Carl Barât]] |} * Baggot Inn, Dublin: [[Yngve Wieland|Yngve & The Innocent]], Bitches with Wolves * Palace Bar, Dublin: [[Yngve Wieland|Yngve & The Innocent]], Fox Avenue * Flannery's Pub, Dublin: Fox Avenue, Carley Connor ;Kuala Lumpur The Arthur's Day celebrations in [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia kicked off on 23 September 2011 (GMT/UTC +8). The event held at Speed City @ [[Selangor Turf Club]] was attended by an estimated crowd of 10,000 and featured performances by [[Taio Cruz]], [[Mizz Nina]], [[Soler (band)|Soler]], [[Dragon Red]], [[Prema Yin]], [[Joe Flizzow]], Take-T (Japan) and Dandee ([[Thailand]]). ;Indonesia Like the global celebration, Guinness Indonesia has also expanded its festivities into a larger audience to grow the footprint of Arthur's Day by bringing even more unforgettable experience through a remarkable concert in 4 cities across Indonesia in [[Jakarta]], [[Medan]], [[Surabaya]] and [[Makassar]]. Internationally renowned artist [[The Script]] performed at the Pullman Hotel Ballroom in Jakarta on 12 November in front of more than 5000 fans who joined together to toast the great Arthur Guinness. They were supported on the night by local bands [[Gugun Blues Shelter]] and Mike's X GroovyL@nd. On 12 November, Guinness Arthur's Day in Jakarta was positioned as the 2nd most trending topic in Twitter media worldwide. The Guinness Arthur's Day Indonesia road show continued; with the American Rock group [[MR. BIG]] performing in Medan, Surabaya and Makassar. MR. BIG hit Medan on the 3 December at Pardede Hall with collaboration from Indonesian rock band [[/rif]], and performed in front of 4000 people who joined the celebration. Next up for MR. BIG was a performance in Surabaya on 7 December at Grand City where the concert was opened by local superstar [[Netral]]. Finally, MR BIG visited Makassar on 10 December and performed the final Arthur's Day 2011 celebrations at Trans Studio. As was fitting for the final celebration of the year, Makassar had the largest attendance with a crowd of over 9000 people. Across the four cities, the Guinness Arthur's Day Indonesia celebration was experienced by over 22,000 people at the four venues. An additional element was that Guinness provided live streaming in 34 outlets all over Indonesia during the concerts. ===2012=== The 2012 promotion of Arthur's day on 27 September included television and billboard advertising under the slogan "Paint the town black". [[Example (musician)|Example]], [[Tinie Tempah]], [[Ellie Goulding]], [[Mika (singer)|Mika]], [[Professor Green]], [[Fatboy Slim]], [[Texas (band)|Texas]] and [[Amy Macdonald]] have been confirmed as headline acts for Arthur's Day 2012. Also on the bill were [[Picturehouse (band)|Picturehouse]], [[Mundy]], Walking on Cars, Dove, [[The Vals]], The Rapparee, The Bonnevilles, [[Lilygreen & Maguire]], The Heads of State, Ard Rí, Midnight Graffiti, [[Fiddler's Green (band)|Fiddler's Green]], Ruaile Buaile, Willie Byrne, Gentry Morris, Shane Butler, Jaker and [[Brush Shiels]]. Arthur's Day 2012 took place on 27 September. ===2013=== Arthur's Day 2013 was celebrated on Thursday 26 September 2013.[http://www.guinness.com/en-ie/arthursday/ Arthur's Day 2013] On 12 August 2013, the line-up for the 2013 Arthur's day was announced, with [[The Script]], [[Emeli Sande]], [[Bobby Womack]] and [[Manic Street Preachers]], among others, headlining the acts that will be playing.[http://www.guinness.com/en-ie/arthursday/bandinfo.html Arthur's Day 2013 headline acts] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927140143/http://www.guinness.com/en-ie/arthursday/bandinfo.html |date=27 September 2013 }}{{cite web|url =http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/the-script-and-manic-street-preachers-among-arthurs-day-lineup-29491834.html |title=The Script and Manic Street Preachers among Arthur's Day line-up|date=12 August 2013|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=13 August 2013 }}{{cite web|url = http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/arthurs-day-about-music-and-talent-not-drinking-29493605.html|title=Arthur's Day 'about music and talent, not drinking'|date=12 August 2013|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=13 August 2013 }}{{cite web|url = http://www.rte.ie/ten/news/2013/0812/467723-arthurs-day-line-up-revealed/|title=Arthur's Day line-up revealed|date=12 August 2013|work=RTÉ News|accessdate=13 August 2013 }} The slogan used on advertisements for 2013 was "Showcasing Ireland's Talent & Creativity", which highlighted the 500+ musical events taking place on the day. Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia will be celebrating Arthur's Day 2013 on 27 September 2013 with Five For Fighting, The All American Rejects & The Wanted at Sepang International Center.[http://www.arthursday.com.my Arthur's Day 2013 Malaysia] In September 2013, a Social Media campaign entitled 'Boycott Arthur's Day' began claiming national and international attention. Irish & International Artists and Musicians have given their support to the campaign which calls on Irish Citizens to 'Say NO to Diageo's boozefest.{{cite web|url = http://alcoholireland.ie/home_news/boycott-guinness-on-arthurs-day-or-should-that-be-diageo-day/|title= Boycott Guinness on Arthur's Day – or Should That Be "Diageo Day"?|date=September 2013|work=Alcohol Ireland|accessdate=25 September 2013}} On 24 September, a live studio debate which included Guinness executive Peter O'Brien was held on Prime Time on [[RTÉ One]] discussing the pros and cons of Arthur's day. Singer [[Christy Moore]] released a single to mark the occasion which he performed on Prime Time.{{cite web|url = http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/guinness-exec-wont-visit-ae-29607994.html|title= Guinness exec won't visit A&E|date=25 September 2013|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=25 September 2013}}{{cite web|url = http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/eilis-ohanlon-we-didnt-need-any-arthurs-day-to-lure-us-into-heavy-drinking-29604284.html|title= We didn't need any Arthur's Day to lure us into heavy drinking|date=24 September 2013|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=25 September 2013}} There has been significant criticism of the event this year due to a 30% increase in ambulance callouts in Dublin on the night in 2012. People have criticised Diageo for inventing a "pseudo-national holiday" to market its products.{{cite web|url = http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/psychologist-slams-arthurs-day-we-dont-need-another-excuse-to-drink-29599504.html|title= Psychologist slams Arthur's Day: ‘We don’t need another excuse to drink’|date=23 September 2013|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=25 September 2013}}{{cite web|url =http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/arthurs-day-bands-should-donate-fees-to-charity-607859.html|title= Arthur's Day bands 'should donate fees to charity'|date=23 September 2013|work=Irish Examiner|accessdate=25 September 2013}} {{cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/shortcuts/2013/sep/24/arthurs-day-ireland-dark-side-guinness|title= Arthur's day: Ireland faces up to the dark side of the Guinness celebrations|date=25 September 2013|work=Guardian|accessdate=25 September 2013}}{{cite web|url = http://www.herald.ie/news/arthurs-day-lethal-for-young-people-29599686.html|title= Arthur's Day 'lethal for young people'|date=25 September 2013|work=Herald|accessdate=25 September 2013}} ==Legacy== Since its cancellation, there have been many reported celebrations of Arthur's Day. In September 2015, MSN News reported that a bar in Jundaí, Brazil was hosting an event for Arthur's Day despite it being abandoned. Later that same September, MSN News reported that Spells Bar in Ballaghaderreen, Co. Roscommon in Ireland was celebrating "The Day Formerly Known As Arthur's Day.{{cite web|url = http://www.msn.com/en-ie/news/national/one-irish-pub-still-celebrated-arthur%e2%80%99s-day-yesterday/ar-AAeMtjb?ocid=spartandhp|title= MSN News - One Irish pub still celebrated Arthur’s Day yesterday|date=24 September 2015|work=MSN News|accessdate=24 September 2015}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.guinness.com/en-ie/arthursday/ Official website] ''[[Hot Press]]'' photos – 2010: [http://www.hotpress.com/photos/photo_st.php?id=6972995 1], [http://www.hotpress.com/photos/photo_st.php?id=6972506 2] * [http://www.arthursday.com.my/ Official Malaysia website] {{Irish Festivals}} [[Category:2000s in Irish music]] [[Category:2010s in Irish music]] [[Category:Anniversaries]] [[Category:Annual events in Ireland]] [[Category:History of Belfast]] [[Category:History of Jakarta]] [[Category:21st century in Kuala Lumpur]] [[Category:Lagos]] [[Category:Music events]] [[Category:Music in Cork (city)]] [[Category:Music in Dublin (city)]] [[Category:Music in Galway (city)]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2009]] [[Category:September events]] [[Category:Social events]] [[Category:Unofficial observances]] [[Category:Events in Lagos]] [[Category:21st century in Lagos]]

revision.text:
[[File:Bannerstone.jpg|thumb|300 px|[[Archaic period in the Americas|Archaic period]] double-notched butterfly '''bannerstone''' from [[Ohio]], ca. 2000 BC. Made of banded [[slate]], a material frequently used in bannerstone manufacture. Bannerstones were used in North America for some 3,000 years beginning in the fourth millennium BC.<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/1979.206.403 Bannerstone] at [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]</ref>]] [[File:Annual report (1916) (18429816591).jpg|thumb|Bannestone in use as a weight on a bowstring-style hand drill (recreation) <ref>Annual report (1916), [[New York State Museum]]</ref>]] [[File:Bannerstone MET DT259422.jpg|thumb|Bannerstone, Ferruginous quartz, 2nd milllenium BC. Found in [[Illinois]].]] '''Bannerstones''' are [[artifact (archaeology)|artifact]]s usually found in the Eastern [[United States]] that are characterized by a centered hole in a symmetrically shaped carved or ground stone. The holes are typically ¼" to ¾" in diameter and extend through a raised portion centered in the stone. They usually are bored all the way through but some have been found with holes that extend only part of the way through. Many are made from banded slate or other colored hard stone. They often have a geometric "wing nut" or "butterfly" shape but are not limited to these. More than just functional artifacts, bannerstones are a form of art that appear in varying shapes, designs, and colors, symbolizing their ceremonial and spiritual importance.
==Debates over function== [[Archaeologists]] have debated over the use of banner stones. Some have suggested that they are [[atlatl]] weights or ceremonial pieces. Others have suggested that they are for drilling, cordage making, or fire making. [[Robert S. Berg]]'s theory proposed that they are part of a kit of tools used to make and repair atlatl darts. Berg's theory has met with a lot of skepticism and resistance because of the previous works of William S. Webb, who proposed that the bannerstone was actually part of an atlatl. Webb cited "in situ" evidence which consisted mainly of bannerstones found in line with atlatl handles and hooks in graves that archaeologists dug up during the construction of the [[Tennessee Valley Authority]]'s massive water control system in the southeast during the early part of the 20th century. It seems that "their primary value lay in their symbolic and aesthetic worth rather than in their tool-like efficiency" <ref>(Berg, 1998:75)</ref> because of the manner in which they were created and later found in archaeological sites.
The ceremonial importance of bannerstones is related to "the psychological uncertainties and physical dangers of daily life among early hunters and gatherers".<ref>(Hero, 2004: 22)</ref> These peoples appealed to the powers of the stone, their creator(s)/deities, and the natural entities around them for protection and survival in the harsh life of the Archaic Period. Being killed in the hunt is one danger that they would be trying to protect themselves from, while giving thanks and recognizing the powers guiding their spears thrown from the atlatls would ensure their success in the hunt. As stated in ''Hero, Hawk, and Open Hand: American Indian Art of the Ancient Midwest and South'', "[bannerstones'] craftsmanship and materials suggest that they also served as emblems of prestige and status conferred upon hunters coming of age, and as supernatural talismans for increasing the spear-throwers efficacy. They may also have served as emblems of clans or other social units".<ref>(2004:26)</ref> This is important because it shows the bannerstone going beyond simple function in the hunt to complex symbolic function in various aspects of society.
==History and context== Bannerstones, as part of a larger picture, indicate that the societies in which they were a part had greater social organization than those in the past. They also indicate a greater interdependence among tribes of various regions. Brian M. Fagan states that, "the production of elaborate and labor-intensive bannerstones (atlatl weights) and stone vessels makes little sense at a local level, but when produced as objects used in broad exchange networks tied to cooperative alliances, such artifacts have considerable value." This is because, as he further states, "many of the important technological innovations of the Archaic resulted from just such successful alliances which made life more secure in an unpredictable environment of patchy food resources".<ref>(2005:379)</ref> Therefore, bannerstones can be seen as indicators of ties between societies in the form of trade, whether it is for the stone that the bannerstone is made out of, the region where the finished bannerstone is found, or the way that it is designed. "Innovations" speak of new ideas entering already existing societies and merging with pre-existing beliefs, resulting in artifacts and art forms such as bannerstones.
Fagan also states, that "from the Mid Archaic onward, people invested more labor in fashioning socially valued artifacts and ornaments like finely ground 'bannerstones'"<ref>(2005:416)</ref> to be used in the networks of trade and formation of "alliances." Bannerstones were created for more than just strict physical survival; they were created for spiritual survival and wellbeing as a part of a cosmological system of belief that both varied between groups of archaic peoples and connected them in the Eastern Woodlands.
The Laurentian is a period of time in the Late Archaic (c. 3200 to c. 1000 BC) that describes the region from New England to Quebec, down into Pennsylvania and New Jersey. The Archaic peoples of this region and time period are one example of a group that produced "polished bannerstones".<ref>(Fagan, 2005:406)</ref>
Bannerstones eventually went out of use as new technologies were invented and spread by trade routes. This includes the bow and arrow which appeared around or before 500 AD.<ref>(Fagan, 2005: 133)</ref> While the bannerstones themselves went out of use, the ceremonial and spiritual importance of these objects did not, being transferred to the new objects that replaced them.
==Notable finds==
An important archaic site containing numerous graves containing bannerstones is at Indian Knoll, Kentucky. At this site, "few of the bannerstones show signs of use. [. . .] They are carved of exotic imported stones with an exceptional artistry that exploits the natural colours, patterns, and striations of the stones to afford maximum visual satisfaction".<ref>(Berlo et al., 1998:75)</ref> This shows both the importance of long distance trade in connecting various archaic societies as well as the importance they placed on the visual appeal of the pieces. This visual appeal would be created in part to please the spirits that the individuals were attempting to persuade for assistance and protection in the hunt, society, and the world as a whole.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}}
==Citations== {{Reflist}}
==References==
*Berlo, Janet C. and Ruth B. Phillips. ''Native North American Art''. Oxford University Press: Oxford, England, 1998. *Fagan, Brian M. ''Ancient North America, Fourth Ed.'' Thames & Hudson: London, 2005. *''Hero, Hawk, and Open Hand: American Indian Art of the Ancient Midwest and South''. Richard R. Townsend and Robert V. Sharp, eds. Yale University Press: New Haven and London, 2004.
==External links== {{Commonscat}} *[https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/1979.206.403/ The Metropolitan Museum of New York entry] *[https://bannerstone.fitnyc.edu/ The Archaic Bannerstone Project] from the Fashion Institute of Technology

revision.text:
The '''British War Memorials Committee''' was a British Government body that throughout 1918 was responsible for the commissioning of artworks to create a memorial to the [[First World War]].<ref name="BEEBtolson">{{cite web |author=Roger Tolson|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/arts/yourpaintings/galleries/collections/imperial-war-museum-690/foreword|title=More about IWM |date=|accessdate=7 October 2014|work=BBC/Your Paintings}}</ref> The Committee was formed in February 1918 when the Department of Information, which had been responsible for war-time propaganda and also operated a war artists scheme, became the [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]] with [[Max Aitken, Lord Beaverbrook|Lord Beaverbrook]] as its Minister. Beaverbrook had been running, from London, the Canadian Government's scheme to commission contemporary art during the First World War and believed Britain would benefit from a similar project. Beaverbrook wanted the British War Memorials Committee to change the direction of Government-sponsored art away from propaganda of short-term value only during the conflict to a collection with a much longer lasting national value. [[Arnold Bennett]], alongside Beaverbrook, was the driving force behind the BWMC and was instrumental in ensuring young artists, including those seen as [[Modernism|modernist]] or [[avant-garde]], were commissioned by the Committee over older British artists, many of whom were associated with the [[Royal Academy]].<ref name="Gough">{{cite book|author=Paul Gough|publisher=Sansom and Company|year=2010|title=A Terrible Beauty: British Artists in the First World War |ISBN=978-1-906593-00-1}}</ref>
==Membership== The original members of the Committee were, :::* [[Alfred Harmsworth, 1st Viscount Northcliffe|Lord Rothermere]], Chair of the BWMC, :::* Alfred Yockney, former editor of [[The Art Journal]] and Secretary of the BWMC, :::* [[Max Aitken, Lord Beaverbrook|Lord Beaverbrook]], :::* [[Arnold Bennett]], :::* Paul G Konody, art critic, :::* [[Charles Masterman]], :::* [[Muirhead Bone]], artist member, :::* [[Robbie Ross]], art advisor, :::* [[Campbell Dodgson]], art advisor, :::* [[Thomas Derrick (artist)|Thomas Derrick]], art advisor,
Also [[William Orpen]] and [[Henry Tonks]] also acted as advisors to the Committee.<ref name="Harries"/>
==Operations== [[Robbie Ross|Robert Ross]] suggested that by ensuring the artists worked to a set of standard size canvases they would produce pictures with a unified identity that would be appropriate for a national memorial. Ross suggested two sizes, 120 by 144 inches based on [[The Surrender of Breda]] by [[Velasquez]] and 72 by 125 inches, the size of [[The Battle of San Romano]] by [[Paolo Uccello]]. Smaller pictures would also be commissioned and an alternative large size, of 72 by 86 inches would be acceptable. In addition, four 'super-pictures' of 20 feet long by 7 feet high were to be commissioned on the theme of cooperation between Britain and its allies.<ref name="Harries"/> The paintings were to be housed in a national [[Hall of Remembrance]] which would be built in London.<ref name="USmalley">{{cite web |author=Ulrike Smalley|url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/history/how-the-british-government-sponsored-the-arts-in-the-first-world-war |title=How The British Government Sponsored The Arts In The First World War |date=|accessdate=5 April 2017|work=Imperial War Museums}}</ref> The architect [[Charles Holden]] was recalled from France, where he was working for the [[Commonwealth War Graves Commission|Imperial War Graves Commission]], to design the building. Muirhead Bone described the structure, which was never built, as a "kind of Pavilion", surrounded by a garden, with a main gallery leading to an oratory with a dedication to the "coming Brotherhood of Man for which we all pray."<ref name="BTruth">{{cite book|author=Richard Cork|publisher=Yale University Press & The Barbican Art Gallery|year=1994|title=A Bitter Truth - Avant Garde Art and the Great War|ISBN=}}</ref>
The BWMC operated three separate schemes, with different terms and conditions, for artists depending on the scale and quantity of work they were expected to produce.
*Scheme One, or the Memorial scheme, was for the production of a single large piece for the central gallery of the Hall of Remembrance for which the artist would be paid £600 for a 20 foot by 7 foot 'super-picture' or £300 for a 72 by 125 or 72 by 86 inch canvas. Smaller works would be bought for £150. Artists on Scheme One contracts included [[John Singer Sargent]], [[Augustus John]], [[Charles Holmes]], [[Walter Bayes]], [[Philip Wilson Steer]], [[George Clausen]] and [[Henry Tonks]].<ref name="Harries"/> *Scheme Two was designed for younger artists who would be paid £300 per annum, plus any military pay they were receiving, in return for which they would turn over their entire output for six months. During this time they would be allowed no outside work at all, including teaching, but were expected to include one piece in the 'memorial' sizes. Artists on Scheme Two included [[Paul Nash (artist)|Paul Nash]], [[John Nash (artist)|John Nash]], [[Colin Gill]], [[Bernard Meninsky]], [[William Roberts (painter)|William Roberts]] and [[Henry Rushbury]]. The artists who had previously been working for the Department of Information war artist scheme, such as [[James McBey]], [[Muirhead Bone]] and [[William Orpen]], were also accommodated under this arrangement. The most prolific of the Scheme Two artists was [[John Laviers Wheatley]] who produced some 40 images of Naval subjects. [[Christopher Nevinson]], was offered a Scheme Two contract but refused and eventually agreed to terms closer to that of Scheme One.<ref name="Harries"/> *Scheme Three gave the BWMC the first option to purchase work in return for facilities and access and was used by [[JD Fergusson]], [[Frank Dobson (sculptor)|Frank Dobson]] and [[William Rothenstein]].
In March 1918 the BWMC submitted a request to the [[War Office]] seeking the release from front-line service of 16 artists. The War Office refused permission for [[Eric Gill]] and [[Jacob Epstein]] to be released, and by the time the Army had processed the requests for [[Stanley Spencer]] and [[Darsie Japp]] the war was almost over. Although Muirhead Bone suggested nineteen well-known, modern women artists, including [[Dora Carrington]] and [[Orovida Pissarro]] for commissions, the BWMC ignored his advice and only recruited three women artists, [[Anna Airy]], [[Dorothy Coke]] and [[Flora Lion]] but did not acquire any paintings from them.<ref name="Beyond">{{cite book|author=Catherine Speck|publisher=Reaktion Books|year=2014|title=Beyond the Battlefield, Women Artists of Two World Wars|ISBN=978 178023 374 1}}</ref> A number of pacifists and [[conscientious objector]]s were approached. Both [[Duncan Grant]] and [[Mark Gertler (artist)|Mark Gertler]] agreed to work for the Committee but the latter was refused permission by the body supervising conscientious objectors. [[Harold Knight]] refused to do any work that could be used as propaganda.<ref name="Harries"/>
==Demise== The BWMC was not without its opponents; many in the Treasury believed that the Government should not be acting as a patron of the arts and the newly formed [[Imperial War Museum]] considered much of what the Committee was doing as part of their remitt. As a peer and a newspaper owner, Beaverbrook himself attracted controversy. Beaverbrook's rival newspapers attacked the workings of the Committee and [[Robbie Ross]] in particular.<ref name="Gough"/> Towards the end of the war the British government gave permission for the proceeds from any BWMC exhibitions to be donated to war charities. Beaverbrook had already, without informing the Government, registered the title "British War Memorials Fund" as just such a private charity. The Acting Secretary of the Ministry of Information, R W Needham, objected that Beaverbrook had no right to generate income for a private charity by exhibiting Government funded artworks and that the artists involved had all worked for reduced fees in the national interest. If Beaverbrook wanted the BWMC to continue beyond the war as a private charity then it would have to become independent of the Ministry and then appeal directly to the public for funds.<ref name="Harries">{{cite book|author=Merion Harries & Susie Harries|publisher=Michael Joseph, The Imperial War Museum & the Tate Gallery|year=1983|title=The War Artists, British Official War Art of the Twentieth Century |ISBN=0 7181 2314 X}}</ref> Beaverbrook abandoned the scheme and the war art collection was brought under the direct control of a new "Pictorial Propaganda Committee" within the Ministry. The Pictorial Propaganda Committee first met on the 24 July 1918 and quickly decided to abandon both the sculpture commissions and the Hall of Remembrance but to maintain the existing painting commissions and to designate the Imperial War Museum, IWM, as the future, permanent, home of the collection. In January 1919, the Secretary of the BWMC, Alfred Yockney joined the IWM to oversee the transition.<ref name="Harries"/>
==Legacy== The BWMC left an artistic legacy that included some of the best art to be produced during World War I. This included the seventeen large paintings intended for the Hall of Remembrance, which included [[Gassed (painting)|''Gassed'']] by [[John Singer Sargent]] and ''[[The Menin Road (painting)|The Menin Road]]'' by [[Paul Nash (artist)|Paul Nash]], plus two large sculpture reliefs by [[Charles Sargeant Jagger]] and [[Gilbert Ledward]] and smaller canvases produced by a total of thirty-one artists.<ref name="Gough"/> The structure and methods used by the BWMC provided the model on which [[Kenneth Clark]] based the, much larger, [[War Artists' Advisory Committee]] during the Second World War.<ref name="Gough"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{World War I}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2015}} The '''Deutsches Filminstitut - DIF''' ("German Film Institute") is an institute for the study of film, based in [[Frankfurt am Main]], [[Germany]]. ==History== The Deutsches Filminstitut was founded on 13 April 1949 as the Deutsches Institut für Filmkunde (DIF). In 1952, the [[Deutsches Filmarchiv]] ("German Film Archive"; founded in [[Marburg]] in 1947 by Hanns Wilhelm Lavies as the Archiv für Filmwissenschaft) was set up as an autonomous department of the DIF, from which it separated again after a reorganisation in 1956.{{cite book|last=Kirchner|first=Daniela|title=Film and Television Collections in Europe: The MAP-TV Guide|year=1995|publisher=Blueprint|location=London|isbn= 1857130154 |pages=179}} On 1 January 1959, Lavies left the DIF and was succeeded as director by [[Max Lippmann]]. Dr Theo Fürstenau became director in 1966, and in 1981 Dr. Gerd Albrecht. The director from 1 February 1997 until September 2017 was Claudia Dillmann. On 30 October 1999, the name was officially changed to Deutsches Filminstitut - DIF. In January 2006 the organisation merged with the [[Deutsches Filmmuseum]] ("German Film Museum"), also based in Frankfurt am Main. ==Functions== The Deutsches Filminstitut has one of the largest film archives in Germany and one of the most comprehensive collections of material on all aspects of [[cinematography]] and [[Film|cinema]]. Current projects include: * The edition and publication of the censorship decisions of the Berliner Film-Oberprüfstelle ("Berlin Film Inspection Point") from 1920 to 1938 * COLLATE - a collaborative system for the annotation and indexing of archive material * [[filmportal.de]] - an internet portal for German film * [[Filmarchives online|filmarchives-online.eu]] - union catalogue of European film archives * EFG - The [[European Film Gateway]] - a single access point to digital collections held in European film archives and cinémathèques The DIF is a founding member of the Deutscher Kinemathekenverbund ("German Union of Cinematheques"). == See also == * [[Museumsufer]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.deutsches-filminstitut.de/}} {{de icon}} ** {{cite web |url= http://www.difarchiv.deutsches-filminstitut.de/dt2tai01.htm |title= Verbotene Bilder, manipulierte Filme (I+II)— Zur Edition der Zensurentscheidungen der Berliner Film-Oberprüfstelle aus den Jahren 1920 bis 1938
|trans-title= Prohibited images, manipulated films (I + II)— For the edition of the censorship decisions of the Berlin Film-Inspectorate from the years 1920 to 1938 |publisher= DIF Archive |language= de }} * [http://www.collate.de COLLATE] - Collaborative System for Annotation, Indexing and Retrieval of Digitized Historical Archive Material *[http://filmportal.de filmportal.de] * [http://www.filmarchives-online.eu filmarchives-online.eu] - union catalogue of European film archives * [http://www.europeanfilmgateway.eu europeanfilmgateway.eu]- a single access point to digital collections held in European film archives and cinémathèques * [http://www.europeanfilmgateway.eu/1914 Films about WW1 on The European Film Gateway] * [http://www.deutschesfilmmuseum.de Deutsches Filmmuseum, Frankfurt am Main] {{Authority control}} [[Category:Film organisations in Germany]] [[Category:Museums in Frankfurt]] [[Category:Cinema museums in Germany]] [[Category:1949 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1949]] [[Category:Film archives]] {{film-org-stub}}
