revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Diesel SpA | logo = Diesel Logo 2015.png | logo_size = 290px | caption = | former_name = MoltexClare O'Connor (25 March 2013). [https://www.forbes.com/sites/clareoconnor/2013/03/06/blue-jean-billionaire-inside-diesel-renzo-rossos-3-billion-denim-empire/ Blue Jean Billionaire: Inside Diesel, Renzo Rosso's $3 Billion Fashion Empire]. ''Forbes''. Accessed May 2014. | type = Private | industry = Fashion | foundation = [[Molvena]], Italy
({{start date and age|1978}}) | founder = {{unbulleted list|[[Adriano Goldschmied]]|[[Renzo Rosso]]}} | location = [[Breganze]] | location_city = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Renzo Rosso, president & founder
Nicola Formichetti, artistic director | products = Clothing and Accessories{{cite web|url=http://www.businessoffashion.com/community/companies/diesel |title=Diesel's Page | BoF Careers |publisher=The Business of Fashion |date= |accessdate=2015-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151124112145/http://www.businessoffashion.com/community/companies/diesel |archivedate=2015-11-24 |df= }} | services = | revenue = €2.9 billion (2015) | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = [[OTB Group]] | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | location_country = [[Italy]] | homepage = {{url|www.diesel.com}} }} '''Diesel S.p.A.''' is an [[Italy|Italian]] retail clothing company, located in [[Breganze]], Italy.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldcrunch.com/food-travel/wine-and-jeans-diesel-founder-renzo-rosso-039-s-organic-vineyard/enzo-rosso-otb-mariostica-diesel-farm-wine/c6s17110/#.VRCKdOHLfIUv |author=Anne Waak |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |title=Wine And Jeans: Diesel Founder Renzo Rosso's Organic Vineyard |date=October 16, 2014}} It sells [[denim]], and other clothing, footwear, and accessories. The clothing line has two different brands: Diesel and Diesel Black Gold. There is also a line for children, called Diesel Kid. The company is known for its surreal advertising campaigns. Since 2013 the creative director has been [[Nicola Formichetti]].{{cite web|url=http://www.style.com/trends/fashion/2015/nicola-formichetti-diesel-tribute |title=Fashion Trends: What's In For Spring, Summer, Fall, and Winter — Vogue |publisher=Style.com |date=2015-11-17 |accessdate=2015-11-23}} Diesel also has a luxury fragrance line which is owned and produced by [[L'Oréal]]. ==History== Diesel founder [[Renzo Rosso]] began stitching jeans on a sewing machine at the age of fifteen. He used his mother’s sewing machine to produce low-riding, bell bottomed jeans, which he would wear himself and sell to his friends for 3500 lira a piece. He later attended an industrial textile manufacturing college in [[Padua]].{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-23630820.html |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |title=Fueller of fashion From making his first pair of Diesel jeans on his mother's sewing machine, Renzo Rosso has gone on to create a superbrand |publisher=The Herald |date=June 3, 2006 |author=Nicola McCormack}} In 1976 Rosso began working for a clothing manufacturer called Moltex, which was owned by [[Adriano Goldschmied]]. After working with the company for two years, he used a loan from his father to buy a 40% holding in the company, which changed its name to Diesel, and marketed [[jeans]] under the Diesel brand and many others.{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/clareoconnor/2013/03/06/blue-jean-billionaire-inside-diesel-renzo-rossos-3-billion-denim-empire/ |publisher=Forbes Magazine |title=Blue Jean Billionaire: Inside Diesel, Renzo Rosso’s $3 Billion Fashion Empire |date=March 6, 2013 |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |author=Clare O’Connor}} Rosso bought out Goldschmied's interest in the Diesel brand name in 1985 for US$500,000, becoming the sole owner of the company. Rosso has said that he learned marketing from the US, creativity from Italy, and systems from Germany.T Surendar, Saumya Roy (June 30, 2010). [http://business.in.com/article/cross-border/diesel-founder-renzo-rosso-knows-what-matters-in-fashion/14622/0 Diesel Founder Renzo Rosso Knows What Matters In Fashion]. Forbes India. Accessed March 2014. In 1990 Russ Togs, Inc. received the license to market and distribute Diesel lines in the United States and Mexico. [[Mitsubishi]] Co. received the license to market and distribute in Japan.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-8801781.html |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |title=Russ Togs gets license for Diesel in U.S., Mexico. (Russ Togs Inc. gets license for Diesel, an Italian apparel line) |publisher=WWD |date=March 5, 1990 |author=Robert Hartlein}} By 1991, Russ Togs was going out of business, and sold Diesel Sportswear to Rosso upon ending the licensing deal. As a result of Russ Togs collapse, the creation of made in the USA Diesel products never came to fruition, and Diesel instead placed its made-in-Italy jeans and clothing in US stores.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-11684089.html |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |title=Diesel Sportswear Inc. (to be sold to Renzo Rosso, owner of Diesel S.p.A.) |publisher=Daily News Record |date=December 11, 1991 |author=Robert Parola}} In 1992, Diesel became the title sponsor for the [[Superbike World Championship|World Superbike racing circuit]].{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eTH-0DNDblEC&pg=RA5-PA26&dq=diesel+laverda&hl=en&sa=X&ei=WmwQVYKWD5OnyATcooDQDw&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=diesel%20laverda&f=false |page=26 |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |title=The End of Laverda? |author=Alan Cathcar |publisher=Cycle World Magazine |date=January 1993}} In 1995, Diesel launched one of the first significant fashion retail websites, which housed images of each of its collections. The first Diesel jeans to be sold online were available in Finland and Sweden starting in 1997. It then opened a virtual store that allowed home delivery for further markets the following year.Franzen and Moriarty, Pg. 5 [[File:Diesel2599.JPG|thumb|Diesel store in [[Kraków]], [[Poland]]]] In 1996, Diesel opened large flagship stores in [[New York City]], [[San Francisco]], [[Rome]], and [[London]], and began to open other mono-brand stores for Diesel in order to augment its points of sale in department and other multi-brand retails stores. Further flagship stores (also known as “StyleLabs”) opened, including stores in [[Berlin]], [[Barcelona]], and [[Paris]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FYGMAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA8 |page=8 |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |title=Fashion Cultures: Theories, Explorations and Analysis |author1=[[Stella Bruzzi]] |author2=Pamela Church Gibson |publisher=Routledge |year=2013}} Diesel also produces illustrated catalogs for its retail lines. The company also won the Premio Risultati award for Best Italian Company of the Year from the [[Bocconi University|Bocconi Institute]] in 1996.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-3456700132.html |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |title=Rosso, Renzo |publisher=Newsmakers 2005 Cumulation |date=January 1, 2005}} In 1998 ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' called Diesel “the label of the moment”. Diesel founder Rosso began purchasing additional fashion companies in 2002, under the parent company Only The Brave, which Diesel was brought under as well. Companies purchased by Only the Brave included [[Maison Margiela|Maison Martin Margiela]], [[Viktor & Rolf]], [[Marni (clothing)|Marni]], and licensing company Staff International.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessoffashion.com/2014/09/bof-exclusive-inside-diesels-reboot.html |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |publisher=Business Of Fashion |title=Inside Diesel’s ‘Reboot’ |author=Vikram Alexei Kansara |date=September 8, 2014}} In 2005 Diesel released the book “Fifty” upon Rosso’s fiftieth birthday, an illustrated history of the company, with a print-run of ten thousand.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-139812729.html |author=David Lipke |title=The Story of Diesel |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |publisher=Daily News Record |date=December 12, 2005}} Diesel's denim's products are produced exclusively in Italy, with many of its products produced by out-sourced factories. Its headquarters are in [[Breganze]], and had twelve international subsidiaries as of 2005.Franzen and Moriarty, Pg. 4 As of 2008, the company had five thousand points of sale across eighty countries, with 270 mono-brand Diesel stores. Diesel itself owns 170 of those, with the rest owned by franchisees.{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=XrcqlxhzdHQC&pg=PA3 |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |page=3 |title=The Science and Art of Branding |author1=Giep Franzen |author2=Sandra Moriarty |publisher=M.E. Sharpe |year=2008}} Turnover was over €1.3 billion in 2009, and by 2010 the company had over 400 stores. In 2012 Diesel founder Rosso was listed on the ''[[Forbes]]'' [[list of billionaires]] for the first time.{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andreamurphy/2012/12/21/diesel-jeans-mogul-is-new-italian-billionaire/ |publisher=Forbes Magazine |date=December 21, 2012 |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |title=Diesel Jeans Mogul Renzo Rosso Joins Ranks Of Forbes Billionaires |author=Andrea Murphy}} In 2015 the company held the exhibition Welcome to Diesel World in Shanghai, which provided an overview of the company’s history, in conjunction with its collection debut.{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/style/diesel-s-nicola-formichetti-takes-c1429110940738.html |title=Diesel's Nicola Formichetti Takes Us To Shanghai |publisher=Yahoo.com |date=2015-04-15 |accessdate=2015-11-23}} Another exhibition was held in [[Tel Aviv]] to mark the company’s twentieth year in Israel.{{cite web|url=http://www.modaonline.it/marchi/d/diesel/2015/diesel-festeggia-20-anni-di-presenza-in-israele-con-un-nuovo-flagship-store-e-con-la-mostra-the-world-of-diesel/ |title=News: |publisher=Modaonline.it |date=2015-06-15 |accessdate=2015-11-23}} ==Fashion lines== [[File:Diesel Black & Gold store in Vienna.jpg|thumb|Diesel Black Gold store in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]]]] While the most popular Diesel apparel item has been denim wear, the company has expanded to include additional forms of clothing. The company has created leather jackets, women’s dresses, and other items.{{cite news |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4381195.html |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |title=Diesel Fuels a Lifestyle |publisher=Chicago Sun-Times |date=March 12, 1997 |author=Maureen Jenkins}} In 1998, Diesel founded an offshoot label called Diesel StyleLab, which produced higher end fashion designs beyond more traditional denim jeans.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-100828080.html |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |title= Keeping Its Cool.(Diesel S.p.A.) |publisher=WWD |date=April 24, 2003}} In the 2000s, the company began to license its brand to other retail manufacturers, in order to create new product categories. These lines included the sunglasses line Diesel Eyewear in partnership with Marcolin, the jewels and watches line Diesel Watches in partnership with [[Fossil, Inc.|Fossil]],{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/fossil-inc-enters-new-license-agreement-with-diesel-for-jewelry-55059162.html |title=Fossil, Inc. Enters New License Agreement With Diesel for Jewelry — re> RICHARDSON, Texas, Aug. 31 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ |publisher=Prnewswire.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-23}} the fragrance line in partnership with [[L’Oreal]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/loreal---luxury-products-division---signs-partnership-agreement-with-diesel-for-launch-of-new-fragrance-line-53551202.html |title=L'OREAL — Luxury Products Division — Signs Partnership Agreement with DIESEL for Launch... - re> PARIS, Jan. 16 /PRNewswire/ |publisher=Prnewswire.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-23}} The production of each line involves supervision from Diesel itself. Diesel has also partnered with Moroso, Seletti, Scavolini, Foscarini, and Berti to create a home furnishings line called Diesel Living,{{cite web|url=http://living.corriere.it/salone-del-mobile/fiera/arredo/2014/diesel-collezione-casa-402009111942.shtml?photo=1&refresh_ce-cp |title=Salone del mobile 2014 - La collezione casa firmata Diesel — Living Corriere |publisher=Living.corriere.it |date= |accessdate=2015-11-23}} with [[Bugaboo International|Bugaboo]] to create strollers,{{cite web|url=http://www.milkmagazine.net/bugaboo-by-diesel-par-the-selby/ |title=The Selby X Bugaboo by Diesel : Famille MacPherson | MilK — Le magazine de mode enfant |publisher=Milkmagazine.net |date=2013-02-06 |accessdate=2015-11-23}} with AVG to create helmets,{{cite web|url=http://www.mugmagazine.com/mug/diesel-kid-the-future-belongs-to-the-little-ones.html |title=Diesel Kid: the future belongs to the little ones | |publisher=Mugmagazine.com |date=2013-01-24 |accessdate=2015-11-23}} with [[Ducati]],{{cite web|url=http://www.gizmag.com/ducati-monster-diesel/21867/ |title=Ducati Monster Diesel launched |publisher=Gizmag.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-23}} and with [[Fiat Automobiles|Fiat]] to create a limited edition [[Fiat 500 (2007)|Fiat 500]].{{cite web|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2008/09/motori/motori-settembre3-2008/fiat-500diesel/fiat-500diesel.html |title=Ecco la Fiat 500 Diesel ma il gasolio non c'entra — Motori |publisher=Repubblica.it |date=2008-09-22 |accessdate=2015-11-23}} Diesel also produces limited edition lines of jeans.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/3164506/Diesel-limited-edition-jeans-modelled-by-Daisy-Lowe-go-on-sale.html |publisher=The Telegraph |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |title=Diesel limited edition jeans modelled by Daisy Lowe go on sale |date=October 9, 2008 |author=Sarah Knapton}} As of 2003, according to Women’s Wear Daily, Diesel had three distinct fashion lines, “Diesel Style Lab, the most pricey fashion-forward designer label; Diesel, a fashion brand that still focuses heavily on denim, and 55DSL, the board sport-inspired streetwear line that blends fashion and function.”{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-100828084.html |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |title=Diesel At 25.(Diesel SpA has come a long way since 1978) |publisher=WWD |date=April 24, 2003}} Style Lab and 55DSL are now defunct. Currently there are two lines at Diesel: Diesel and Diesel Black Gold.{{cite web|url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/2014/12/16/andrea-rosso-diesel-myar-interview/ |title=Andrea Rosso talks MYAR, 55DSL, Diesel and More |publisher=Highsnobiety |date=2014-12-16 |accessdate=2015-11-23}} Diesel Black Gold is the luxury ready-to-wear line and was launched in 2008 during the [[New York Fashion Week]].{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-174327632.html |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |title=From the Guy That Invented $100 Distressed Denim, a Schmancy New Line! |publisher=The New York Observer |date=February 7, 2008}} That year the company also partnered with [[Adidas]] to co-produce a sport denim line.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-176477121.html |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |title=ADIDAS UNVEILS NEW STORE CONCEPT; CO-BRANDED DENIM FROM DIESEL ALSO HITS RACKS AT REDESIGNED ADIDAS ORIGINALS STORES GLOBALLY |publisher=Daily News Record |date=February 11, 2008 |author=David Lipke}} In 2013 Diesel underwent a re-branding effort, reorganizing both the business structure and marketing methodologies. ==Advertising== [[File:Dieselwall.jpg|thumb|right|200px|"Dieselwall" in [[Berlin]]]] Starting in 1991, Diesel has been known for producing ads that invoke surreal images in lieu of direct product details, in partnership with Swedish ad agency Paradiset DDB, Stockholm. These included 1997 ads portraying life in Communist North Korea (shot in Hong Kong).{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2ugCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA24 |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |title=Hip Service |publisher=New York Magazine |date=September 22, 1997 |page=24 |author=Barbara Lippert}} Another ad campaign imitated automobile crashes.Bruzzi and Gibson, Pg. 143 Campaigns have also used social consciousness as a theme, ironic plays on global issues (such as their Global Warming Ready campaign featuring post-global warming backdrops in global locations), as well as anti-establishment messages.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E9vSm3KokMcC&pg=PT31 |page=31 |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |title= Battleground: The Media [2 Volumes] |author1=Robin Andersen |author2=Jonathan Gray |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=2007}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vUxn0R7ARDAC&pg=PA216 |page=216 |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |title=Consumer Behavior and Culture: Consequences for Global Marketing and Advertising |author=Marieke de Mooij |publisher=SAGE Publications |year=2010}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rLt48XwnW1cC&pg=PA157 |page=157 |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |title=Marketing Communications: A Brand Narrative Approach |author1=Micael Dahlen |author2=Fredrik Lange |author3=Terry Smith |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |year=2010}} Michael Chevalier has critiqued the retail stores, stating that he believes that the stores's merchandise is presented in a confusing way in order to get customers to interact with the sales staff.{{cite book | title=Luxury Brand Management | publisher=John Wiley & Sons | author=Chevalier, Michel | year=2012 | location=Singapore | isbn=978-1-118-17176-9}} During the late 1990s, Diesel produced CD-ROMs and other computer content, including the computer game “Digital Adrenalin—55DSL”. In 2007 Diesel sponsored a music contest, Diesel-U-Music.{{cite web|url=http://www.hearya.com/2007/04/12/attention-unsigned-bands-diesel-music-contest/|title=Attention Unsigned Bands – Diesel Music Contest|date=April 12, 2007}} From January to September 2008, Diesel spent $5.8 million on U.S. advertising, according to [[TNS Media Intelligence]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wwd.com/media-news/fashion-memopad/another-world-springing-back-the-mastheads-continue-to-shrink-1890028|title=Another World...Springing Back...The Mastheads Continue to Shrink...|last=Lipke|first=David|work=[[Women's Wear Daily|WWD]]|date=December 12, 2008}} The Grand Prix award at the [[Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity|Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival]] was won by Diesel in 1997, in 2001 for a campaign featuring the fictitious newspaper “The Daily African”, and for the ad campaign “Be Stupid” in 2010.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5HeZPdZtQLMC&pg=PA49 |page=49 |accessdate=March 23, 2015 |title=Deep Secrets |author=Niobe Way |publisher=Harvard University Press |year=2011}} There is a Diesel Art Gallery in [[Tokyo]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tokyoweekender.com/events/incurable-egoist-masahisa-fukase/ |title=The Incurable Egoist Masahisa Fukase | Events |publisher=Tokyoweekender.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-23}} In 2009 the head of Diesel's US division, Steve Birkhold, left the company shortly after agreeing a deal to sell cut-priced jeans through [[Macy's]].James Covert (November 14, 2009). [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/business/diesel_out_of_fuel_LbE3qgHRwNmCfETkts1JxK#ixzz0tUpXHhnu Diesel out of fuel]. ''New York Post''. Accessed March 2014. In 2015 [[Liam Hemsworth]] appeared in an ad for Only The Brave.{{cite web|last=Barns |first=Sarah |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3087691/Hunger-Games-actor-Liam-Hemsworth-celebrity-face-Diesel-Brave.html |title=Hunger Games' Liam Hemsworth becomes new face of Diesel Only The Brave | Daily Mail Online |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2015-05-19 |accessdate=2015-11-23}} [[Winnie Harlow]] also appeared in ads that year as well.{{cite web|last=London |first=Bianca |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2937873/Model-cruelly-labelled-cow-zebra-having-Michael-Jackson-s-skin-condition-new-star-Diesel-s-spring-campaign.html |title=Model with vitiligo Winnie Harlow stars in Diesel's spring campaign |work=Daily Mail |date= |accessdate=2015-11-23}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Diesel (brand)}} * [http://www.diesel.com Official Website] {{L'Oreal Group}} {{men's undergarments}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Diesel (Brand)}} [[Category:Clothing brands of Italy]] [[Category:Clothing brands]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1978]] [[Category:Clothing companies of Italy]] [[Category:Companies based in Veneto]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1978]] [[Category:Italian brands]] [[Category:Jeans by brand]] [[Category:L'Oréal]] [[Category:Shoe companies of Italy]] [[Category:Underwear brands]] [[Category:Watch manufacturing companies of Italy]] [[Category:Eyewear companies of Italy]]

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.comment: /* Urdu variation of diwan */ simplify heading
revision.text:
{{Other uses|Diwan (disambiguation){{!}}Diwan}} {{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=February 2014}} {{Lead too short|date=October 2009}} }} [[File:Colophon portrait from the Khamsa of Nizami - BL Or. MS 12208 f. 325v.jpg|thumb|[[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] scribes at work, collecting ''Diwan''s]] In Muslim cultures of the Middle East, North Africa, Sicily{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MypbfKdMePIC&lpg=PA356&ots=_qJyZO98m_&dq=Ibn%2520Hamdis%2520sicily%2520diwan&pg=PA356#v=onepage&q=Ibn%2520Hamdis%2520sicily%2520diwan&f=false|title=Medieval Islamic Civilization: A-K, index|last=Meri|first=Josef W.|last2=Bacharach|first2=Jere L.|date=2006-01-01|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9780415966917|language=en}} and South Asia, a '''Diwan''' ({{lang-fa|دیوان}}, ''divân'', {{lang-ar|ديوان}}, ''dīwān'') is a collection of poems by one author, usually excluding his or her long poems ([[Masnavi (poetic form)|mathnawī]]).{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia= [[Encyclopædia Iranica]] |year= 2011|contribution=DĪVĀN | first = François de | last = Blois | contribution-url = http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/divan }} These poems, frequently sung or set to music, were often composed and collected in the imperial courts of various sultanates and were very well known for their ability to inspire. ==Etymology== The English usage of the phrase "diwan poetry" comes from the [[Arabic Language|Arabic]] word ''diwan'' (دیوان), which is loaned from [[Persian Language|Persian]], and designated a list or register.Alain Rey et al., ''Dictionnaire historique de la langue française'', new ed. (Robert, 1995), vol. 1, p. 617. The Persian word derived from the Persian ''dibir'' meaning ''writer'' or ''scribe''. ''Diwan'' was also [[Loanword|borrowed]] into [[Armenian language|Armenian]], [[Arabic]], [[Urdu]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]]. In Persian, Turkish and other languages the term ''diwan'' came to mean a collection of poems by a single author, as in ''selected works'', or the whole body of work of a poet. Thus ''Diwan-e Mir'' would be the ''Collected works of [[Mir Taqi Mir]]'' and so on. The first use of the term in this sense is attributed to [[Rudaki]]. The term ''divan'' was used in titles of poetic works in French, beginning in 1697, but was a rare and didactic usage, though one that was revived by its famous appearance in [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]]'s ''[[West–östlicher Divan]]'' (Poems of West and East), a work published in 1819 that reflected the poet's abiding interest in Middle Eastern and specifically Persian literature. This word has also been applied in a similar way to collections of [[Jewish literature#Poetry|Hebrew poetry]] and to poetry of [[al-Andalus]]. ==Symbolism== [[File:Divan-of-Hafiz-Binding-Gul-u-Bulbul.jpg|thumb|Rose and nightingale on the binding of a Divan of Hafiz (Iran, 1842)]] Ottoman Divan poetry was a highly [[ritual]]ized and [[symbol]]ic art form. From the Persian poetry that largely inspired it, it inherited a wealth of [[symbol]]s whose meanings and interrelationships—both of similitude (مراعات نظير ''mura'ât-i nazîr'' / تناسب ''tenâsüb'') and opposition (تضاد ''tezâd'')—were more or less prescribed. Examples of prevalent symbols that, to some extent, oppose one another include, among others: * the [[nightingale]] (بلبل ''bülbül'') – the [[rose]] (ﮔل ''gül'') * the world (جهان ''cihan''; عالم ''‘âlem'') – the rosegarden (ﮔﻠﺴﺘﺎن ''gülistan''; ﮔﻠﺸﻦ ''gülşen'') * the ascetic (زاهد ''zâhid'') – the [[dervish]] (درويش ''derviş'') As the opposition of "the ascetic" and "the dervish" suggests, Divan poetry—much like Turkish folk poetry—was heavily influenced by [[Sufism#Basic beliefs|Sufi thought]]. One of the primary characteristics of Divan poetry, however—as of the Persian poetry before it—was its mingling of the mystical Sufi element with a profane and even erotic element. Thus, the pairing of "the nightingale" and "the rose" simultaneously suggests two different relationships: * the relationship between the fervent lover ("the nightingale") and the inconstant beloved ("the rose") * the relationship between the individual Sufi practitioner (who is often characterized in Sufism as a lover) and [[Allah|God]] (who is considered the ultimate source and object of love) Similarly, "the world" refers simultaneously to the physical world and to this physical world considered as the abode of sorrow and impermanence, while "the rosegarden" refers simultaneously to a literal garden and to [[Heaven#In Islam|the garden of Paradise]]. "The nightingale", or suffering lover, is often seen as situated—both literally and figuratively—in "the world", while "the rose", or beloved, is seen as being in "the rosegarden".{{cite book|last1=Andrews|first1=Walter G.|last2=Kalpaklı|first2=Mehmet|title=The age of beloveds : love and the beloved in early-modern Ottoman and European culture and society|date=2005|publisher=Duke University Press|location=Durham|isbn=0-8223-3424-0|edition=2. print.}} Divan poetry was composed through the constant juxtaposition of many such images within a strict metrical framework, thus allowing numerous potential meanings to emerge. A brief example is the following line of verse, or ''mısra'' (مصراع), by the 18th-century [[Qadi|judge]] and poet Hayatî Efendi: :بر گل مى وار بو گلشن ﻋالمدﻪ خارسز :''Bir gül mü var bu gülşen-i ‘âlemde hârsız''Pala, İskender (1995) ''Divân Şiiri Antolojisi: Dîvânü'd-Devâvîn'' Akçağ Yayınları, Kızılay, Ankara, p. 425, {{ISBN|975-338-081-X}} :("Does any rose, in this rosegarden world, lack thorns?") Here, the nightingale is only implied (as being the poet/lover), while the rose, or beloved, is shown to be capable of inflicting pain with its thorns (خار ''hâr''). The world, as a result, is seen as having both positive aspects (it is a rosegarden, and thus analogous to the garden of Paradise) and negative aspects (it is a rosegarden full of thorns, and thus different from the garden of Paradise). ==Development== [[File:Ottoman Garden.jpg|thumb|upright|Ottoman garden party, with poet, guest, and winebearer; from the 16th-century ''Dîvân-ı Bâkî'']] As for the development of Divan poetry over the more than 500 years of its existence, that is—as the Ottomanist Walter G. Andrews points out—a study still in its infancy;Andrews, ''Ottoman Lyric Poetry: An Anthology'', 22–23 clearly defined movements and periods have not yet been decided upon. Early in the history of the tradition, the Persian influence was very strong, but this was mitigated somewhat through the influence of poets such as the [[Azerbaijani people|Azerbaijani]] [[Nesîmî]] (?–1417?) and the [[Uyghur people|Uyghur]] [[Alisher Navoi|Ali Şîr Nevâî]] (1441–1501), both of whom offered strong arguments for the poetic status of the Turkic languages as against the much-venerated Persian. Partly as a result of such arguments, Divan poetry in its strongest period—from the 16th to the 18th centuries—came to display a unique balance of Persian and Turkish elements, until the Persian influence began to predominate again in the early 19th century. Despite the lack of certainty regarding the stylistic movements and periods of Divan poetry, however, certain highly different styles are clear enough, and can perhaps be seen as exemplified by certain poets: [[File:Fuzuli.jpg|thumb|100px|Fuzûlî (1483?–1556), Divan poet of [[Azerbaijanis|Azeri]] origin]] * [[Fuzûlî]] (1483?–1556); a unique poet who wrote with equal skill in Azeri Turkish,Peter Rollberg. The modern encyclopedia of Russian and Soviet literature (including Non-Russian and Emigre literatures) / Edited by Harry B. Weber. — Academic International Press, 1987. — Volume 8. — Page 76.
In Mesopotamia Fuzuli was in intimate contact with three cultures — Turkic, Arabic, and Persian. '''Besides his native Azeri''', he learned Arabic and Persian at an early age and acquired a through command of the literatures in all three languages, an accomplishment in which the cosmopolitan literary and scholarly circles of Hilla played an important role.
 Persian, and Arabic, and who came to be as influential in Persian as in Divan poetry * [[Bâkî]] (1526–1600); a poet of great rhetorical power and linguistic subtlety whose skill in using the pre-established [[Trope (linguistics)|tropes]] of the Divan tradition is quite representative of the poetry in the time of [[Suleiman the Magnificent|Süleyman the Magnificent]] * Nef‘î (1570?–1635); a poet considered the master of the ''kasîde'' (a kind of [[panegyric]]), as well as being known for his harshly satirical poems, which led to his [[Capital punishment|execution]] * [[Yusuf Nabi|Nâbî]] (1642–1712); a poet who wrote a number of socially oriented poems critical of the [[Stagnation of the Ottoman Empire|stagnation period]] of Ottoman history * [[Nedîm]] (1681?–1730); a revolutionary poet of the [[Tulip period|Tulip Era]] of Ottoman history, who infused the rather élite and abstruse language of Divan poetry with numerous simpler, populist elements * Şeyh Gâlib (1757–1799); a poet of the [[Mevlevi|Mevlevî]] [[Tariqah|Sufi order]] whose work is considered the culmination of the highly complex so-called "Indian style" (سبك هندى ''sebk-i hindî'') The vast majority of Divan poetry was [[Lyric poetry|lyric]] in nature: either ''gazel''s (which make up the greatest part of the repertoire of the tradition), or ''kasîde''s. There were, however, other common genres, most particularly the ''mesnevî'', a kind of [[Courtly romance|verse romance]] and thus a variety of [[narrative poetry]]; the two most notable examples of this form are the ''[[Leyli and Majnun|Leylî vü Mecnun]]'' (ليلى و مجنون) of Fuzûlî and the ''Hüsn ü Aşk'' (حسن و عشق; "Beauty and Love") of Şeyh Gâlib. ==Urdu variation== In [[Urdu poetry]] diwan are also a collection of poems, but here they are mainly [[ghazal]]s.[http://www.columbia.edu/itc/mealac/pritchett/00urduhindilinks/bailey/000introduction.pdf ''A History of Urdu literature''] by T. Grahame Bailey; ''Introduction'' == See also == *[[Anthology]] *[[Arabic literature]] *[[Persian literature]] *[[Ottoman poetry]] *[[Early Modern literature]] *[[Meter (poetry)#Ottoman Turkish|Poetic meter of Ottoman Turkish]] *[[:Category:Ottoman divan poets|Ottoman divan poets]] (Category) ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia= [[Encyclopædia Iranica]] |year= 1989|contribution=Bolbol "nightingale" – In Persian Literature | first = Jerome W. | last = Clinton | contribution-url = http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/bolbol-nightingale }} * {{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia= [[Encyclopædia Iranica]] |year= 2001|contribution= Gol O Bolbol | first = Layla S.| last = Diba| contribution-url = http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/gol-o-bolbol }} == External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061109040459/http://www.osmanlimedeniyeti.com/Edebiyat/ Many examples of Ottoman Divan poetry], in Turkish, from [[Internet Archive]] *[http://ekitap.kulturturizm.gov.tr/BelgeGoster.aspx?F6E10F8892433CFF3948C44161D1F3EAF4576EE45B9AA497 Divan-Full Text-Republic of Turkey Ministry of Culture and Tourism], in Turkish {{Persian literature}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Diwan (Poetry)}} [[Category:Arabic poetry]] [[Category:Arabic anthologies]] [[Category:Poetry movements]] [[Category:Persian poetry|*]] [[Category:Ottoman poetry]] [[Category:Early Modern literature]] [[Category:Urdu poetry]] [[Category:Azerbaijani poetry]]

revision.comment: Bluth's career started in 1977, over 40 years ago.
revision.text:
The following is a '''list of unproduced Don Bluth projects''' in roughly chronological order. During a career that has spanned over 40 years, [[Don Bluth]] has worked on projects which never progressed beyond the [[pre-production]] stage under his direction.
==1970s==
===''Piper''=== * An animated short film based on the famous ''[[Pied Piper of Hamelin]]'' story was in the works in the early 1970s. Not much is known about this short but bits and pieces can be found online.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0WHDRFl0rSs|title=Sections of Piper Short|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>https://twitter.com/DonBluth/status/940981302722887680</ref>
==1980s==
===''East of the Sun and West of the Moon''=== * In the early 1980s, Bluth Productions began work on an animated feature film entitled ''[[East of the Sun and West of the Moon#Film adaptations|East of the Sun and West of the Moon]]''.<ref>John Grant, p 35, ''Masters of Animation'', Special Effects Are Revolutionizing Film"</ref> Ultimately, the film was never made due to a loss of financial backing,<ref>"Newswatch: Bluth animation film goes bankrupt," ''[[The Comics Journal]]'' #98 (May 1985), p. 19.</ref> even though the film was heavily into production at the time of its cancellation. They decided to make ''[[An American Tail]]'' as its 2nd animated film, starting production in December 1984 and released in November 1986.
===''The Velveteen Rabbit''=== * One of the animated films that Don Bluth was going to work with [[Steven Spielberg]] on, where it is an animation adaptation of the story ''[[The Velveteen Rabbit]]'', which is about a toy rabbit trying to become a real rabbit after his beloved human child owner is forced to abandon him.<ref>https://m.imgur.com/gallery/2wjY1</ref>
===''Laserdisc arcade games''=== Plans for other arcade games similar to ''[[Dragon's Lair]]'' and ''[[Space Ace]]'' such as: *'''The Sea Beast''', where a 1940s sailor named Barnacle Bill tries to rescue a mermaid princess from a nasty sea beast. *'''Jason and the Golden Fleece''', based on the famous Greek legend [[Jason (Greek mythology)|Jason]]. *'''Devil's Island''', where you play a shipwreck passenger trying to find treasure, rescue a jungle princess and take down a corrupt civilization. *'''Haywire''', where you play a [[Charlie Chaplin]] like character trying to survive and escape a huge factory run by an evil business man. *'''Drac''', where [[Van Helsing]] has to save his girlfriend from [[Dracula]] and his monster minions of evil before she becomes one of his brides. *'''Cro Magnon''', where you play a [[Cro-Magnon|Cro Magnon]] caveman as he battles vicious dinosaurs, scary creatures and an evil warlord. *'''Sorceress''', where you control a sorceress to protect her island from temple robbers and poachers. Due to the [[Video game crash of 1983|1983 video game crash]], leading to the bankruptcy of both Bluth and [[Cinematronics]], these ideas were scrapped, with the only laserdisc game released by Bluth was ''[[Dragon's Lair II: Time Warp]]'' in 1991.<ref>https://twitter.com/donbluth/status/664179126303985664</ref>
===''Star Baby''=== * An animated film that Don Bluth was going to work with Steven Spielberg. No info on this unmade film has been found yet, but was hinted to be an outer space adventure like movie.<ref>https://m.imgur.com/gallery/2wjY1</ref>
===''Strawberry Fields Forever''=== * After acquiring the rights to [[The Beatles]]{{'}} songs in the mid-1980's, [[Michael Jackson]] approached Bluth with a movie idea called ''Strawberry Fields Forever''. The film would have had animated ''[[Fantasia (1940 film)|Fantasia]]''-style vignettes featuring Beatles songs, similar to ''[[Yellow Submarine (album)|Yellow Submarine]]''. Not only did Don Bluth agree to it, he also planned on making it entirely in [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]]. Had the movie been made, it would have predated the ground-breaking ''[[Toy Story]]'' by about eight years. Further along in the project, the premise became revamped so that characters from Beatles songs (like [[Mean Mr. Mustard|Mr. Mustard]] and [[I Am the Walrus|the Walrus]]) would act as New York City gangsters. Among other reasons, the main reason why the project fell through was because the surviving Beatles members denied permission to use their images in an animated film. The only part of the film that managed to be made was test footage of the "Beatles gangsters."<ref>https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/WhatCouldHaveBeen/UnsortedAnimatedFilm</ref>
===''Satyrday''=== * An animated film that Don Bluth was going to make with Steven Spielberg and [[George Lucas]]. The project is based on a story by [[Steven Bauer]] where a young boy in a fantasy world goes on a quest to get the moon back and save the sun from evil forces. Some of the film's concepts latter went into the French animated film ''[[Mune: Guardian of the Moon]]''.<ref>https://m.imgur.com/gallery/2wjY1</ref>
===''The Little Blue Whale''=== * An animated film about a little girl and her animal friends try to protect a little whale from evil whalers. The project was canceled by its co-production studio [[Carolco Pictures]] after the commercial and critically failure of its first animated film ''[[Pound Puppies and the Legend of Big Paw]]''.<ref>https://m.imgur.com/gallery/2wjY1</ref>
===''Beauty and the Beast''=== * An animated feature film adaptation of the classic fairy tale directed by Don Bluth. While some concept arts were made in 1984, the film's production was canceled when Don Bluth and the film's distributor [[Columbia Pictures|Columbia]] heard the news of [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Disney]] making an animated film with the [[Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)|same name]].<ref>https://m.imgur.com/gallery/2wjY1</ref>
==1990s==
===''Kandu: Song of the Ice Whale''=== * An animated feature film that involves whales but more of a discovery experience through a whale's eye with a beautiful score and narration. While storyboards, where made in 1991, the film's production, was canceled due to problems with studios and Don Bluth was working on other productions in the 1990s.<ref>https://m.imgur.com/gallery/2wjY1</ref>
===''Jawbreaker''=== * A TV mini-series of a boy finds a magical tooth, while a video showed a clip of what the show is.<ref>[http://dragonslairthemovie.com/jawbreaker-story/ “Jawbreaker” Story]</ref> The mini-series' production was shut down when Don Bluth started [[Fox Animation Studios]].
===''The Magic Pencils''=== * A canceled animated short film that was centered around a magical talking pencils starring [[Dom DeLuise]], until Don Bluth started Fox Animation Studios.<ref>https://m.imgur.com/gallery/2wjY1</ref>
===''Deep Wizardry''=== * A rumor was said that after Don Bluth and Fox Animation Studios would release ''[[Anastasia (1997 film)|Anastasia]]'' one of their next films was going to be an animated film based on the book ''[[Deep Wizardry]]'' by [[Diane Duane]]. However nothing came through and the project was canceled.<ref>https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/WhatCouldHaveBeen/UnsortedAnimatedFilm</ref>
===''Quintaglio Ascension''=== * One of Don Bluth and Fox Animation Studios' next films after ''Anastasia'' was going to be a animated film based on the ''[[Quintaglio Ascension]]'' trilogy by [[Robert J. Sawyer]]. But nothing new came and it's production was shut down.<ref>https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/WhatCouldHaveBeen/UnsortedAnimatedFilm</ref>
===''Ice Age''=== * The film was planned to be a comedy-less drama similar to ''[[The Land Before Time]]'', but due to the closure of Fox Animation Studios and the box office disaster of ''[[Titan A.E.]]'' the film was lent over to [[Blue Sky Studios]] who turned it into a dramedy.<ref>https://m.imgur.com/gallery/2wjY1</ref>
===''The Belgariad''=== * Another animated film that was going to be planed by Don Bluth and Fox Animation Studios was a animated film based on ''[[The Belgariad]]'' series by [[David Eddings]]. However the production for that film was canceled after nothing came through.<ref>https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/WhatCouldHaveBeen/UnsortedAnimatedFilm</ref>
===''The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy''=== * When [[20th Century Fox]] got the rights to ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]'' series by [[Douglas Adams]], they wanted Don Bluth and Fox Animation Studios to make an animated film of it. But production was canceled when problems happened at Fox Animation Studios and [[Touchstone Pictures]] got the rights to make movie from Fox which became [[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (film)|the live-action film of the same name]].<ref>https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/WhatCouldHaveBeen/UnsortedAnimatedFilm</ref>
==2000s==
===''I-Ninja 2''=== * A sequel to the 2003 game ''[[I-Ninja]]'' was planned, which had input from Bluth. Work on the sequel started soon after the first game's release, but its studio [[Argonaut Games]] had some economic problems and eventually closed down in October 2004. The few aspects remaining from ''I-Ninja 2''{{'s}} development are some concept drawings.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.unseen64.net/2009/12/03/i-ninja-2-ps2-xbox-gamecube-cancelled/|title=I-Ninja 2 Cancelled|website=Unseen64|accessdate=November 6, 2018}}</ref>
===''Pac-Man Adventures''=== * Originally planned to have worked on in partnership with [[Namco]] around 2003. The project was scrapped due to financial problems on Namco's part leading to their merger with [[Bandai]] in 2007 and whatever development assets were left over was made into ''[[Pac Man World 3]]'' with no involvement from Bluth.<ref>http://ecollections.scad.edu/iii/cpro/DigitalItemViewPage.external?lang=eng&sp=1000278&sp=T&sp=Pall%2CRu1000001%40%2CQdon+bluth&suite=def</ref><ref>https://twitter.com/donbluth/status/677270407037059072</ref>
==2010s==
===''Dragon's Lair'' film=== * In the 1980s a film version of ''Dragon's Lair'' was planned, with [[Alan Dean Foster]] involved in shaping the story. The project fell apart due to low interest from other studios.<ref>Cawley, John. ''[http://www.cataroo.com/DBtvfeat.html Games on TV and The Big Screen]''</ref> On October 26, 2015, Bluth and Goldman started a [[Kickstarter]] campaign to create a teaser for an animated feature-length ''Dragon's Lair'' prequel film, their first feature film since ''Titan A.E.''<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/donbluth/dragons-lair-the-movie?ref=video |title=Dragon’s Lair: The Movie (Canceled) by Don Bluth & Gary Goldman — Kickstarter |website=Kickstarter.com |date= |accessdate=September 13, 2016}}</ref> The Kickstarter funding was canceled when not enough funds were made close to the deadline, but an [[Indiegogo]] page for the project was created in its place.<ref name= "indiegogo">{{cite web|url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/dragon-s-lair-returns/x/12369452 |title=Dragons Lair Returns |website=Indiegogo.com |date= |accessdate=September 13, 2016}}</ref> On December 14, 2015, the Indiegogo campaign reached its goal of $250,000 to produce a teaser, 14 days after the campaign launched, and got more than twice the budget on January 16, 2016.<ref name = indiegogo/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/10/26/9617632/dragons-lair-movie-kickstarter-don-bluth |title=Dragon's Lair creators turn to Kickstarter to raise money for Dragon's Lair: The Movie - Polygon |accessdate=September 13, 2016}}</ref> Bluth and Goldman have announced that the film will provide more backstory for Dirk and Daphne and that Daphne will show that she is not a "blonde airhead".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/dragons-lair-movie-wont-depict-sexualized-version-/1100-6433325/ |title=Dragon's Lair Movie Won't Depict "Sexualized" Version of Princess Daphne - GameSpot |accessdate=September 13, 2016}}</ref> Since then, there have been no further production news.

{{distinguish|Dorkbot (malware)}} {{Infobox organization | name = dorkbot | image = File:Dorkbot_logo.jpg | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = a '''dorkbot''' logo | motto = "People doing strange things with electricity." | region_served = Global | website = {{url|http://dorkbot.org/}} | remarks = | founder = Douglas Repetto | formation = {{start-date|2000}} | purpose = Artistic, Educational }}
'''Dorkbot''' is a group of affiliated organizations worldwide that sponsor [[grassroots]] meetings of artists, engineers, designers, scientists, inventors, and anyone else working under the very broad umbrella of [[electronic art]].<ref>{{Cite news| issn = 0028-792X| last = Wilkinson| first = Alec| title = Incomprehensible| work = The New Yorker| accessdate = 2014-05-30| date = 2004-06-07| url = http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2004/06/07/040607ta_talk_wilkinson}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| last = Chillag| first = Ian| title = Dorks Try to Mingle in New York| work = NPR.org| accessdate = 2014-05-30| date = 2008-02-07| url = https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=18764927}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news| issn = 0362-4331| last = Braiker| first = Brian| title = When Art and Science Collide, a Dorkbot Meeting Begins| work = The New York Times| accessdate = 2014-05-30| date = 2006-01-17| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/17/science/17dork.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news| issn = 0190-8286| last = Beckman| first = Rachel| title = Hearts of Dorkness| work = The Washington Post| accessdate = 2014-05-30| date = 2006-12-21| url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/12/20/AR2006122001723.html}}</ref> The dorkbot [[motto]] is "people doing strange things with electricity".
Started by Douglas Repetto<ref>{{Cite web| last = Metz| first = Rachel| title = The Geek Mind Behind Dorkbot| work = WIRED| accessdate = 2014-05-30| date = 2006-04-24| url = http://archive.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2006/04/70697?currentPage=all}}</ref> at the [[Columbia University]] [[Computer Music Center]] in 2000, dorkbot has spread around the world, with over 100 chapters either planning or actively holding meetings as of 2010.<ref>The current list of chapters, with map, can be seen at [http://dorkbot.org dorkbot.org].</ref>
The purpose of dorkbot meetings is to nurture a local electronic arts community and to encourage emerging, and established, artists to present new works for informal peer review. While many of the dorkbot groups hold their meetings at universities and students are encouraged to attend, dorkbot meetings are not restricted in any way to the academic community. Dorkbot groups encourage the free exchange of ideas on the electronic arts, and regular attendees of one dorkbot will often visit another when they are travelling, serving as informal ambassadors between groups.
==See also== * [[ArtBots]] * [[Café Scientifique]] * [[Hackspace]] * [[Maker Faire]] * [[Nerd Nite]]
